yacovm (Thu, 09 Feb 2017 23:11:39 GMT):
Some CRs, in descending order of complexity: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/5787/ Makes gossip support intra-organizational endpoints and inter-organizational endpoints (the 1st change set in the series) https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/5809/ Makes gossip re-connect to bootstrap peers if they're not available https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/5811/ *Not a gossip change set, a really simple one* - Makes the `peer` cli commands not puke MSP logs when run by setting the relevant log invocations from Info to Debug.

C0rWin (Thu, 09 Feb 2017 23:49:06 GMT):
and another one: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3793/ :)

JonathanLevi (Fri, 10 Feb 2017 21:16:40 GMT):
Hi, just a quick one: Any suggestion(s) regarding the environment var naming in fabric-ca? Opened this after a nice CR by @baohua, and I thought we should run it by others as well: https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-2188 [I think that FABRIC_CA_.... is a better prefix, but I didn't want to short-circuit it. Please chime in should you have an objection...]

JonathanLevi (Fri, 10 Feb 2017 21:26:03 GMT):
@cbf, @mastersingh24, @smithbk ^^^

smithbk (Fri, 10 Feb 2017 21:43:17 GMT):
The reason I made FABRIC_CA_CLIENT and FABRIC_CA_SERVER different was to avoid any potential conflict, just to be safe. In reality, I'm not aware of any other than home directory, which we could still make FABRIC_CA_CLIENT_HOME and FABRIC_CA_SERVER_HOME

smithbk (Fri, 10 Feb 2017 21:44:23 GMT):
while all others would just be FABRIC_CA prefix

baohua (Sat, 11 Feb 2017 00:19:49 GMT):
sure, and also suggest to consider if we need to keep the same style between fabric-peer, fabric-orderer and fabric-ca. currently they have names of `PEER_CFG_PATH`, `ORDERER_CFG_PATH` and `FABRIC_CA_HOME` as the default configuration paths.

baohua (Sat, 11 Feb 2017 00:40:22 GMT):
Make update on https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-2118, welcome for comments. I guess better to consider this change ASAP, as the cfg variables are important for all bootup, test and usage things.

baohua (Sat, 11 Feb 2017 00:40:44 GMT):
Thanks!

muralisr (Sat, 11 Feb 2017 17:19:37 GMT):
@binhn @mastersingh24 I see one problem in a premature unmarshalling of pb.Response ... I think it masked a original problem for failures (possibly timeout). As unmarshall can pass if the bits are in the right place we probably didn't see it sooner.

muralisr (Sat, 11 Feb 2017 17:20:30 GMT):
This will also explain why its passing locally (we did not face timeouts and unmarshalled good responses)

muralisr (Sat, 11 Feb 2017 17:20:33 GMT):
working on a fix

yacovm (Sun, 12 Feb 2017 16:22:54 GMT):
[FAB-2198]: Starting to refactor Gossip message signature mechanism https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/5903/ ---> https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/5907/ The 1st commit of the two doesn't change/add any logic, it's just cosmetics. The 2nd commit simply makes our membership module use a map instead of a slice, nothing too hard to review IMO.

yacovm (Sun, 12 Feb 2017 16:22:54 GMT):
[FAB-2198]: Starting to refactor Gossip message signature mechanism (because protobuf marshaling is non-deterministic) The right depends on the left: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/5903/ ---> https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/5907/ The 1st commit of the two doesn't change/add any logic, it's just cosmetics. The 2nd commit simply makes our membership module use a map instead of a slice, nothing too hard to review IMO.

greg.haskins (Tue, 14 Feb 2017 22:46:50 GMT):

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 00:57:38 GMT):
@muralisr all passing CI now: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6059/

muralisr (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 00:58:54 GMT):
@greg.haskins I was looking at that... couldn't figure out why the entry was removed in platforms_test.go ... ?

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 00:59:25 GMT):
oh because in the earlier form of the patch I was trying to enforce /src/$pkg/.*

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 00:59:32 GMT):
but that broke a lot of tests

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 00:59:39 GMT):
that are just packaging the entire GOPATH

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:00:08 GMT):
and I decided that it was probably safer to just stick to excluding binaries than to try to impose policy on the golang packages themselves

muralisr (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:00:18 GMT):
ok

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:00:31 GMT):
but then I forgot to remove the test to was looking for that enforcement

muralisr (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:00:59 GMT):
ok

muralisr (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:01:13 GMT):
I didn't connect those dots.

muralisr (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:01:14 GMT):
thanks

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:01:35 GMT):
here was the original logic that drove the test: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6059/1..3/core/chaincode/platforms/golang/platform.go

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:01:35 GMT):
here was the original logic that warranted the test: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6059/1..3/core/chaincode/platforms/golang/platform.go

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:02:43 GMT):
but it turns out the CLI/platform is overzealous and just grabs $GOPATH/src/.*\.(go|c|h|yaml|json)

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:03:03 GMT):
(which I think I knew, but had forgotten until the tests went belly up

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:03:54 GMT):
ideally, we would replicate similar logic to ./scripts/goListFiles.sh

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:04:15 GMT):
i.e. take the chaincode package and then walk the deps/transitives backwards

baohua (Thu, 16 Feb 2017 01:08:56 GMT):

mastersingh24 (Sat, 25 Feb 2017 22:52:30 GMT):
@sanchezl @muralisr @greg.haskins - re: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6529/ - maybe this will work for something like Vagrant or will work if you only have fabric and fabric-ca in you $GOPATH/src, but due to https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6059/3 we've made it 100% impossible for someone to run anything natively / outside of Docker if they have additional projects in their $GOPATH/src . And personally I am not going to go change all the file permissions of all of my Go projects

muralisr (Sat, 25 Feb 2017 22:56:50 GMT):
@mastersingh24 I remember discussion with @greg.haskins on this... and (correct me if I misremember Greg) the decision was to make it strict and revisit if it becomes painful... maybe time has come to revisit

mastersingh24 (Sat, 25 Feb 2017 23:00:28 GMT):
well I think there *might* be a larger problem in that the CLI commands which package chaincode end up believing that $GOPATH/src contains only the chaincode you want to deploy

mastersingh24 (Sat, 25 Feb 2017 23:00:34 GMT):
that's the real issue

mastersingh24 (Sat, 25 Feb 2017 23:01:30 GMT):
so for example any of the tests which involve chaincode install/deploy will fail when run directly vi `go test` in the package folder if you have multiple projects in your $GOLANG/src folder

mastersingh24 (Sat, 25 Feb 2017 23:02:18 GMT):
so not sure which *problem* to fix or maybe we don't care :(

mastersingh24 (Sat, 25 Feb 2017 23:02:50 GMT):
I mean I love fabric, but I do have other Go projects on my laptop

muralisr (Sat, 25 Feb 2017 23:06:22 GMT):
right :-).. we will run into this for sure in dev envs

mastersingh24 (Sat, 25 Feb 2017 23:08:43 GMT):
well I'll try to get to it tomorrow. I think I'm too old to take redeyes (took one home from PHX last night)

jimthematrix (Sun, 26 Feb 2017 00:46:21 GMT):

github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer/node.initSysCCs() /Users/jimzhang/workspace/go/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer/node/start.go:82 +0x33 github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer/node.serve(0x4c8f358, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0, 0x0) /Users/jimzhang/workspace/go/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer/node/start.go:162 +0x978```

greg.haskins (Sun, 26 Feb 2017 01:15:03 GMT):
@mastersingh24 @muralisr I think there are two problems

greg.haskins (Sun, 26 Feb 2017 01:16:24 GMT):
1) the SDK/CLI should be using "go list" to determine only exactly the list of packages required rather than assuming $GOPATH/*

greg.haskins (Sun, 26 Feb 2017 01:16:54 GMT):
(See scripts/goListDeps.sh for concept)

greg.haskins (Sun, 26 Feb 2017 01:18:03 GMT):
2) once the minimal set is ascertained, the SDK/CLI should be managing how the tarball is formed, including filtering bogus mode bits

greg.haskins (Sun, 26 Feb 2017 01:18:35 GMT):
IMHO

greg.haskins (Sun, 26 Feb 2017 01:20:18 GMT):
For reference: https://dave.cheney.net/2014/09/14/go-list-your-swiss-army-knife

muralisr (Sun, 26 Feb 2017 01:56:37 GMT):
@jimthematrix it needs `-ldflags "-X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.Version=0.7.0-snapshot- -X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.BaseVersion=0.3.0"`

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 19:36:26 GMT):
To the maintainers who review: what's up with the pattern of `foo/foobar/` (or `foo/barfoo`) that seems to be the norm across the codebase? Why is this sort of stuttering allowed?

yacovm (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 19:43:07 GMT):
you mean packages and file names?

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 19:44:32 GMT):
Filenames, but the same rule applies to packages.

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 19:44:36 GMT):
`foo/bar` where the package `bar` will be imported as `foobar` by a consumer not in that tree is the only sane way of going at it.

mastersingh24 (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:22:39 GMT):
@kostas - I think I know what you mean, but can you point at a real example? (perhaps what made you post this)

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:23:36 GMT):
@mastersingh24: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/tree/master/core/scc and all the `*cc` inside is a good example of this.

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:23:49 GMT):
I got more -- hold on.

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:25:00 GMT):
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/tree/master/common/ledger/blkstorage/fsblkstorage

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:25:17 GMT):
(^^ This is actually what prompted me to post this.)

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:25:52 GMT):
And of course in our `orderer` package we have some stuttering with `ledger/orderledger`, etc. that I will most definitely get rid of.

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:26:35 GMT):
So, going to the `scc/lccc` example: `lccc` should be renamed `lifecycle`, and that should be the name of the package as well.

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:26:35 GMT):
So, going to the `scc/lccc` example: `lccc` should be renamed to `lifecycle`, and that should be the name of the package as well.

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:27:30 GMT):
Everyone else who wishes to import `lifecycle` may import it as `lccc` (via aliasing) if they choose to do so.

mastersingh24 (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:27:30 GMT):
yep - makes sense

mastersingh24 (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:28:15 GMT):
my complaints start at a different level - common,core, core/common, peer, core/peer, etc

mastersingh24 (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:28:29 GMT):
sh*t all over the place

greg.haskins (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 20:38:00 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/fabric-pr-review?msg=KCKCSKbbh6Z9EZned) @kostas I had this exact thought this morning

muralisr (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:45:03 GMT):
but lifcycle of what ?

yacovm (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:45:24 GMT):
lifecycle is under chaincode so it can be implicitly derived I guess

muralisr (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:45:25 GMT):
to be exact, lifecyclechaincode

muralisr (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:45:31 GMT):
ie, lccc :-)

greg.haskins (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:47:46 GMT):
I agree with @kostas on this one, the relationship in the tree can convey appropriate meaning

greg.haskins (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:48:29 GMT):
so ./systemchaincode/lifecycle is better than stuttering

greg.haskins (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:48:37 GMT):
or whatever

greg.haskins (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:48:58 GMT):
but also, lifecycle* is better than lccc

greg.haskins (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:49:10 GMT):
people are always asking me what that acronym is

greg.haskins (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:49:14 GMT):
;)

greg.haskins (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 21:49:50 GMT):
to be clear, I am primarily referring to the fs hierarchy...i have no problem with "lccc" as the chaincodeID

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 22:26:57 GMT):
@muralisr: As Greg and Yacov have noted, the tree conveys the meaning.

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 22:27:56 GMT):
As I have also noted, if you have someone consuming this package outside the `scc/*` tree, then they may import `scc/lifecycle` as `lccc` (or whatever name they wish really).

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 22:28:35 GMT):
But it is simply wrong to do `scc/lccc/`, you have folder hierarchy there for a reason.

kostas (Tue, 28 Feb 2017 22:28:35 GMT):
But it is simply wrong to do `scc/lccc/`, you have a folder hierarchy there for a reason.

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 09:59:11 GMT):

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 09:59:11 GMT):

https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6811/ - moving leader election configuration parameters to core.yaml

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:43:17 GMT):
For 6811 I need one more +2. Somebody, please?

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:46:07 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6735 - fixed leader election integration test, want to re-enable it... @binhn , @muralisr , @mastersingh24

muralisr (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:47:48 GMT):
@gennadyl ```While using real gossip as communication middleware for leader election it become impossible to point to what peer will become leader after previous leader shutdown. So test was changed to check only amount of leaders, but not what peer is a leader.```

muralisr (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:47:48 GMT):
@gennadyl ```While using real gossip as communication middleware for leader election it become impossible to point to what peer will become leader after previous leader shutdown. So test was changed to check only amount of leaders, but not what peer is a leader.```

muralisr (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:48:43 GMT):
so you are saying it's not possible to know beforehand who will become leader

muralisr (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:49:18 GMT):
but we can know who is the leader once elected, correct ?

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:49:40 GMT):
Short answer - yes

muralisr (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:49:45 GMT):
ok

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:50:57 GMT):
Long answer - I can to guess who will be leader with high probability

muralisr (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:51:10 GMT):
that is interesting :-)

muralisr (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:52:08 GMT):
curious now.... can you explain a bit more ?

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 13:53:47 GMT):
Sure.

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:04:04 GMT):
Each peer can be in 3 states - leader, follower and in leader election.

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:04:33 GMT):
If peer is leader, it sends once in while leadership message to all other peers

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:05:42 GMT):
If peer is follower, it expect to get leadership message in predefined period of time

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:06:24 GMT):
If follower don't get message in this period of time, it decide to start leader lection

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:06:52 GMT):
It sends propose message to all peers and wait

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:08:13 GMT):
In case it didn't get non propose message from other peer, then my.peerId > his.peerId, nor leadership message,

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:08:52 GMT):
it starts to send leadership message to all peers - become leader

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:09:51 GMT):
so, peers discover in different periods of time that they didn't get leadership message from leader and go to election

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:11:28 GMT):
so, peer with higher peerId can send propose message, wait leader election period of time and send leadership message

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:12:03 GMT):
before it gets propose message from peer with lower peerId

gennadyl (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:12:26 GMT):
Thats all

muralisr (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:19:39 GMT):
a bit like HSRP sounds like.. thanks for the explanation, @gennadyl

muralisr (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:20:55 GMT):
+2ed but will wait for @C0rWin or @yacovm review

yacovm (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:21:29 GMT):
I just don't understand the https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6735/15/gossip/service/gossip_service_test.go@123 stuff

yacovm (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:21:46 GMT):
why do you have this `gossips[i].(*gossipServiceImpl).chains[channelName].Stop()` inside each loop?

yacovm (Sat, 04 Mar 2017 14:28:58 GMT):
Anyhow- it looks kinda ok to me, I commented on that thing and will merge, you can write in the change set after.

jimthematrix (Sun, 05 Mar 2017 07:17:20 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6869/ - adding a default chaincode policy of 'signed by any member of org by mspid' where mspid is the submitter's local MSP. this is only the initial step for policy support but is required for the new end2end tests to work (because the built-in default policy uses the "DEFAULT" msp id which of course should not be used in real setup)

jimthematrix (Sun, 05 Mar 2017 07:18:03 GMT):
@mastersingh24 @jyellick @aso @yacovm ^^^

jimthematrix (Sun, 05 Mar 2017 17:23:00 GMT):
http://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/6881 Enhance the default endorsement policy, the initial step in 6869 creates a default policy that looks for the specific signature from the org that submitted the "instantiate()" proposal. the enhancement creates a more robust policy that looks for a single signature from any of the chain's participating orgs, which are discovered from the chain's config block. @mastersingh24 @binhn @jyellick @aso @yacovm

jyellick (Sun, 05 Mar 2017 17:41:32 GMT):

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 06:11:46 GMT):
Now on that note, why isn't a CR such as *Remove cli from fabric-ca* - a self-contained, atomic CR that requires so many others?

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 06:11:46 GMT):
Now on that note, why isn't a CR such as *Remove cli from fabric-ca* - a self-contained, atomic CR - and instead, it requires/linked to so many other CRs? (for example)

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 06:12:54 GMT):
Being able to merge self-contained items (with sign-offs) will save us all plenty of time (and iterations)

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:02:27 GMT):
I have been trying to unclog some of you... (of all sections/areas: gossip, fabric-ca, some of Jason's very nice stuff wrt to the Proposer/config...)

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:03:02 GMT):
But I feel like we have a few "camps", components that are "building up" a *LOT* of logic.

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:03:02 GMT):
But I feel like we have a few "camps", components that are "building up" a *LOT* of pending/logic that we slowly approve +2 at a time.

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:04:03 GMT):
If possible, and I know it is a bit difficult at times, to submit some smaller independent issues... it will allow us to merge things gradually so that we can better test the "integration" of these.

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:04:51 GMT):
It's what I asked Keith to do earlier this morning, similar with the backlog that Yacov uploaded here (and I did just merge a bug-fix), and it's the same with Jason's (very nice!) work.

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:04:52 GMT):
----

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:05:02 GMT):
Keep in mind that the build cycles are slow.

yacovm (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:05:10 GMT):
Wait, my commits in the last week are either bug fixes or a single JIRA item

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:05:22 GMT):
Nothing personal (Yacov)

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:05:22 GMT):
Nothing personal (Yacov) - yours was self-contained and I have merged it, right?

yacovm (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:05:23 GMT):
There isn't really lots of logic that is changed

yacovm (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:05:27 GMT):
just saying :)

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:06:29 GMT):
It's just a more general statement... that even though we approve things... in many cases, we end up being able to merge them only a few days later. Which can be a bit/more risky as we "integrate" a lot in "one go".

yacovm (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:07:18 GMT):
Yeah I totally agree about the configuration stuff.

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:08:30 GMT):
Not blaming anything/anyone specifically. Just saying that the sooner we merge and test - the better these days. And the more we review/approve and can't wait... the more "risk" we build up as the upcoming merges grow.

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:08:30 GMT):
Not blaming anything/anyone specifically. Just saying that the sooner we merge and test - the better these days. And the more we review/approve and can't merge (postpone the merging)... the more "risk" we build up as the upcoming merges grow, and we'll end up with even less time for testing an "integrated"/combined version of the "master" branch.

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:08:30 GMT):
Not blaming anything/anyone specifically. Just saying that the sooner we merge and test stuff that we need to have as part of the alpha cut - the better (these days). And the more we review/approve and can't merge (postpone the merging, while we know it will be needed)... the more "risk" we build up as the upcoming merges grow, and we'll end up with even less time for testing an "integrated"/combined version of the "master" branch.

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:08:30 GMT):
Not blaming anything/anyone specifically. Just saying that the sooner we merge and test stuff that we need to have as part of the alpha cut - the better (these days). And the more we review/approve and can't merge (postpone the merging step), while we know it will be needed... the more "risk" we build up as the upcoming merges grow, and we'll end up with even less time for testing an "integrated"/combined version of the "master" branch.

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:09:15 GMT):
Just a request/suggestion for everybody - as a "by stander" who took a quick snapshot at the current state of gerrit.

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:48:55 GMT):

Message Attachments

JonathanLevi (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 15:49:34 GMT):
As an example (really without loss of generality ;-))

dave.enyeart (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 17:25:44 GMT):
Chaincode gets an error if iterating beyond the hard-coded query limit of 100. This change adds a configurable query limit (default 10000) to help people get past the error scenarios: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6683/

dave.enyeart (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 17:26:49 GMT):
This is a proposed fix for beta. The larger fix to re-enable batching results between shim and peer is riskier and therefore targeted for post-beta.

dave.enyeart (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 17:28:17 GMT):
@muralisr as the maintainer with the most knowledge in this area, the others would probably defer to your judgement

harsha (Tue, 07 Mar 2017 18:05:44 GMT):

@muralisr @mastersingh24 with CR 6991, the "peer chaincode" CLI is now about as efficient as I think it can possibly be in terms of codepackage size: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6991/

greg.haskins (Wed, 08 Mar 2017 14:31:03 GMT):
for instance, packaging example02 results in a 2421 byte payload, whereas it used to be over a MB

jyellick (Wed, 08 Mar 2017 15:47:47 GMT):
Talked some with @JonathanLevi about this yesterday. In the interest of not stopping development, but also stabilizing code for alpha, I'm tagging CRs which should not be pulled in before alpha as `[FAB-XXXX] (PA) `. I post it here as a suggested convention to allow reviewers to easily determine which CRs should be considered for alpha.

jyellick (Wed, 08 Mar 2017 15:47:47 GMT):
Talked some with @JonathanLevi about this yesterday. In the interest of not stopping development, but also stabilizing code for alpha, I'm tagging CRs which should not be pulled in before alpha as `[FAB-XXXX] (PA) `. (Thought being PA can mean post-alpha) I post it here as a suggested convention to allow reviewers to easily determine which CRs should be considered for alpha.

JonathanLevi (Wed, 08 Mar 2017 15:54:28 GMT):
Yes, let's try to test that new stuff we need - as much as we can...

muralisr (Wed, 08 Mar 2017 15:56:55 GMT):
talking of testing, people who know this please to ignore the following steps I typically use to do e2e testing :-)

muralisr (Wed, 08 Mar 2017 15:58:31 GMT):
```make clean make peer make peer-docker make orderer-docker cd examples/e2e-cli ./network__setup.sh up if everything went well you should see Query Result: 90 2017-03-08 14:59:08.968 UTC [main] main -> INFO 006 Exiting..... ===================== Query on PEER3 on channel 'mychannel' is successful ===================== ===================== All GOOD, End-2-End execution completed ===================== to cleanup ./network_setup.sh down```

muralisr (Wed, 08 Mar 2017 15:59:34 GMT):
that tests a bit of manythings - gossip, orderer, channel create/join, ledger

yacovm (Wed, 08 Mar 2017 16:17:25 GMT):
Same thing here @muralisr ``` Query Result: 90 2017-03-08 16:17:03.059 UTC [main] main -> INFO 006 Exiting..... ===================== Query on PEER3 on channel 'mychannel' is successful ===================== ===================== All GOOD, End-2-End execution completed ===================== ```

yacovm (Wed, 08 Mar 2017 16:17:33 GMT):
Nice script btw (whoever wrote it)

ruslan.kryukov (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 04:22:44 GMT):
As for couchDB, recently we have made stress test, which included invoke requests to fabric, a lot of them, 1000reqs with 50 threads.. so couchdb just hanged when we were doing test, finally we turned off couchdb and currently we use embdedd levelDB

ruslan.kryukov (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 04:23:58 GMT):
(Tiny stress test)

muralisr (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 13:03:30 GMT):
@ruslan.kryukov and the same test worked with levelDB I assume ?

ruslan.kryukov (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 13:03:48 GMT):
yes

ruslan.kryukov (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 13:04:20 GMT):
leveldb works fast

muralisr (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 13:04:58 GMT):
can you relate this in fabric-ledger too please ?

ruslan.kryukov (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 13:05:36 GMT):
done

muralisr (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 13:05:52 GMT):
also, does the test verify the results of the invoke after commit ?

ruslan.kryukov (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 13:08:49 GMT):
yes, I had status 200

muralisr (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 13:13:12 GMT):
sorry.. let me be be clearer. The invoke returns 200 which is good. But the transacation that the invoke submits to orderer and finally gets committed to the ledger. Once committed, will be good to verify the chaincode state (say using a query)

dave.enyeart (Fri, 10 Mar 2017 13:57:39 GMT):
Thanks @ruslan.kryukov CouchDB has not yet gone through optimization, performance, stress test. That will be done under https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-2725

mastersingh24 (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 17:29:00 GMT):
@jyellick - how many of those changes are "breaking" changes for what we just tagged as 1.0.0-alpha?

yacovm (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 17:37:16 GMT):
The first on his list is mine, not breaking anything, just adds flexibiity

yacovm (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 17:37:16 GMT):
The first on his list is mine, does not break anything, just adds flexibiity

mastersingh24 (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 17:41:39 GMT):
to be clear, the reason for my question is because it looks like the docs might tell people to run the e2ecli sample and the only place to get it from is the fabric repo. and of course we need e2ecli to keep working. so if we change it for any reason, then people using it with the alpha images will be broken.

mastersingh24 (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 17:42:24 GMT):
So to avoid that, perhaps we'll need to ZIP up the e2ecli sample as is today and have people download the ZIP rather than get it from the repo

jyellick (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 17:47:39 GMT):
FAB-1302 / Gerrit-7105 is the breaking one. Everything before that I believe should be benign.

jyellick (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 17:58:08 GMT):
(But really, I would say if we want to point people to the fabric repo, we need to point them to the alpha commit, or, fork them a branch to point them to)

mastersingh24 (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 18:00:34 GMT):
I personally don't want to point people at the fabric repo

mastersingh24 (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 18:01:01 GMT):
and uses tags and branches will confuse many people who just want to use the stuff anyway

mastersingh24 (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 18:02:50 GMT):
@greg.haskins - 2 questions: 1) would you be opposed to adding the ZIP of just the e2ecli sample (or maybe all the samples) to https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/releases ? (I know they are in the ZIP but would be nice to just have a samples ZIP) 2) how hard would it be to do that?

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 18:04:09 GMT):
@mastersingh24 we should probably shift to nexus.hyperledger.org vs gh releases

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 18:04:27 GMT):
but once that happens, I think it would be trivial for CI to publish what we want

greg.haskins (Thu, 16 Mar 2017 18:04:44 GMT):
I have no opinion on the e2e zip file being included

RahulBagaria (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 04:03:22 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 16:54:26 GMT):
an easy one with no effect on the e2e - https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7205/ (added a few handy features to cryptogen)

muralisr (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:20:00 GMT):
@mastersingh24 so basically generate an MSP (admincerts,signcerts, key and certs) and make it useable for TLS ?

muralisr (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:20:49 GMT):
I thought it already did the former ?

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:26:01 GMT):
I added a feature to actually generate user certs and and admin cert for each org

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:26:01 GMT):
I added a feature to actually generate user certs and an admin cert for each org

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:26:15 GMT):
admincerts takes an explicit cert not a root cert - so i fixed that as well

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:26:53 GMT):
the certs can now be used for TLS as well with openssl clients (without the key usage openssl clients - used by Node, Python, etc - will reject the certs)

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:27:39 GMT):
they should provide the material required when channel create require authorization

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:27:39 GMT):
this should also provide all the material required for when channel create requires authorization (which is in one of Jason's CRs)

yacovm (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:29:13 GMT):
But why do we need root CA certs to be used as TLS server certs?

yacovm (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:30:13 GMT):
isn't what's done in https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7205/2/common/tools/cryptogen/ca/generator.go@103 enough

yacovm (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:30:13 GMT):
isn't what's done in https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7205/2/common/tools/cryptogen/ca/generator.go@103 enough?

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:31:39 GMT):
ah - that's laziness for using the defaults for fabric-ca which use the same certs for both signing and TLS if you don't explicitly provide TLS certs

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:31:39 GMT):
ah - that's laziness for using the defaults for fabric-ca which uses the same certs for both signing and TLS if you don't explicitly provide TLS certs

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:32:39 GMT):
line 103 is used when the CA signs a cert but not for creating it's own self-signed cert

yacovm (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:33:22 GMT):
yeah, I understand that. I thought it was for fabric-CA but didn't know `cryptogen` was supposed to be used also for `fabric-ca`.

yacovm (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 17:33:22 GMT):
> line 103 is used when the CA signs a cert but not for creating it's own self-signed cert yeah, I understand that. I thought it was for fabric-CA but didn't know `cryptogen` was supposed to be used also for `fabric-ca`.

mastersingh24 (Fri, 17 Mar 2017 18:03:55 GMT):
you don't have to use fabric-ca, but if you wanted to add more users or peers to your org, you could use the stuff in the `ca` folder to start a fabric-ca for your org

troyronda (Wed, 29 Mar 2017 14:30:18 GMT):
Small patch to fix docker-compose usage in fabric's unit-test (when docker-compose down isn't called at the end of unit test and make dist-clean all is then invoked you will then get "No Such Image" until docker-compose rm or down is manually invoked: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7447/

troyronda (Wed, 29 Mar 2017 14:30:32 GMT):
(known issue in docker-compose: https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/1113)

sanchezl (Fri, 31 Mar 2017 17:28:38 GMT):
It's mainly a "code style" level cleanup. Best to do now before we're stuck with it post 1.0. Java SDK manually merges protos, so nothing new there for them. (IMO, I've made it easier to merge as they now don't have to add package names every time)

muralisr (Fri, 31 Mar 2017 18:39:11 GMT):
@binhn `Is it necessary to change the proto filenames? ` from what I understood it helps to change the filenames so the Java side will generate nice classnames.

muralisr (Fri, 31 Mar 2017 18:40:24 GMT):
somefile.proto will generate either `class Somefile` or `class somefile` whereas "some_file" will generate `SomeFile`

muralisr (Fri, 31 Mar 2017 18:40:42 GMT):
(@sanchezl to correct above)

muralisr (Fri, 31 Mar 2017 18:40:42 GMT):
( @sanchezl to correct above)

muralisr (Fri, 31 Mar 2017 18:40:50 GMT):
so it seemed to make sense

binhn (Fri, 31 Mar 2017 18:54:55 GMT):

binhn (Fri, 31 Mar 2017 18:59:33 GMT):
there are 3 filenames changed msp_config, chaincode_event, and chaincode_shim

muralisr (Sun, 02 Apr 2017 20:08:03 GMT):
@mastersingh24 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7591 added instantiation policy to the protos specified in the same way as endorsement policy

muralisr (Sun, 02 Apr 2017 20:09:31 GMT):
by including the policy in the LCCC record at instantiation time, we will be able to validate it uniformly at commit time on all peers in the channel (including those that don't have the chaincode installed)

mastersingh24 (Sun, 02 Apr 2017 20:10:32 GMT):
awesome

yacovm (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 12:52:48 GMT):

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 12:53:59 GMT):

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 12:54:07 GMT):
@yacovm - thanks for pointing this out

binhn (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 13:31:16 GMT):
@yacovm ok, so either nil or not nil, but it seems that we should never get to nil condition

yacovm (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 13:34:02 GMT):
I think likewise. If doesn't make sense that you have a chaincode invocation going on, without the ability of having the signed proposal, as the signed proposal is simply passed to `init` of `chaincode.go`.

yacovm (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 13:35:47 GMT):
It's a shame that the `GetCreator` method also returns an error, since it's extracted at `init` time as well. But it's too late for that, that ship has sailed.

binhn (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 13:39:06 GMT):
good point

binhn (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 14:03:10 GMT):
unfortunately there are several that follow this pattern, including getTransient, getBinding, getArgsSlice, GetTxTimestamp , so either we change them all (may be difficult for folks) or keep the pattern for 1 more function

yacovm (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 14:05:11 GMT):

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 15:46:43 GMT):
a few easy ones: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7679/ https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7681/

JonathanLevi (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:20:02 GMT):
@greg.haskins: re 7679, I suggest we do both...

JonathanLevi (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:20:31 GMT):
(Let's use the file mode bits and also update the mount options...)

JonathanLevi (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:20:40 GMT):
What do you think?

sanchezl (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:26:13 GMT):
@muralisr , @JonathanLevi – I've rebased https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7089 and removed 1 file from the patchset.

muralisr (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:30:11 GMT):
@greg.haskins I keep coming back to this one thing with https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6991.. While it is attractive in (1) picking up exactly what is needed from go dependencies (2) keeping the size small, the other side is that (1) user cannot add arbitrary files and (2) we have to support this in other SDKs for consistency and uniformity.. the later is not a big issue (we can package/ prereq go env in a usable manner) but the former worries me a bit. While it may sound nice to say "we will not allow anything other than go chaincode depedencies" it may have practical limitations when user wants to inject non go files.

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:31:37 GMT):
Honestly, I think that is "ok", and here is why

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:31:58 GMT):
in order for us to support _anything_ else other than .go files, it really needs to be a spec

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:33:12 GMT):
that spec would encompass everything from how the chaincode deployment package is formed, how it is processed on the peer, and how it is presented and available to the chaincode application environment are not something we can just say "just in case"

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:33:34 GMT):
for example: perhaps we model something like java ./resources and CLASSPATH

muralisr (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:33:43 GMT):
ok

muralisr (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:33:54 GMT):
I remember now touching upon that

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:34:02 GMT):
and on the peer, we take ./resources, put it in /var/chaincode/resources, and then set an envvar

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:34:14 GMT):
this is all fine, but it does need to be defined

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:34:38 GMT):
until that happens, I just say KISS...that is the spec

muralisr (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:34:59 GMT):
I think you are right...

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:35:00 GMT):
when/if we define whatever this enhanced feature is, lets spec it, and if necessary, create a new TYPE for it

muralisr (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:35:21 GMT):
let me wait for other comments (but will run the CR later today)

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:35:40 GMT):
ok

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:36:16 GMT):
heres my hope...that kind of enhanced usage can be captured in either chaintool, or a chaintool like utility

muralisr (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:36:27 GMT):
keeping it minimal lays the foundation to grow in the right direction (a la the java resource example)

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:36:38 GMT):
i want to capture this "package" process in a tool so that the SDKs dont need to keep reimplementing it

muralisr (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:36:49 GMT):
yes

muralisr (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:36:57 GMT):
its all coming back to me :-)

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:37:15 GMT):
so to that point, lets keep the existing GOLANG/JAVA spec simple, and we can build up from there

muralisr (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:37:36 GMT):
in agreement

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:37:40 GMT):
cool

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:38:52 GMT):
just to emphasize the point, keep in mind that today we dont preserve the code package in the runtime anyway

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:39:04 GMT):
we only have baseos + chaincode-binary

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:39:26 GMT):
so even if we permitted something other than .go files, it gets tossed away after compilation

muralisr (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 16:41:50 GMT):
true.. although at one point we did keep stuff around (so I remember)... or put it another way, just like we put the TLS cert, we *could* chose to put such files (as we'd have to when doing resources properly)

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 17:06:44 GMT):
right, it just need to be a spec...code will rely on it, etc, so we want to treat it as any other ABI extending mechanism

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 17:07:08 GMT):
e.g. we can load the code in /var/chaincode/resources today and somewhere else tomorrow

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 17:07:08 GMT):
e.g. we can't load the code in /var/chaincode/resources today and somewhere else tomorrow

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:13:37 GMT):
@greg.haskins - then we need to define a spec for the code structure for chaincode. We can't just make arbitrary changes which basically make this stuff unusable

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:16:15 GMT):
BTW - did the CR which only brings in the chaincode src (and not everything under $GOPATH/src) make it in at some point?

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:16:33 GMT):
@mastersingh24 I think we are arguing the same thing

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:16:50 GMT):
That's 6991, needs approval

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:17:08 GMT):
We are - but I would have preferred the spec before tightening things up ;)

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:17:31 GMT):
ah - 6991 - got it

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:17:35 GMT):
I knew there was one out tehrte

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:17:35 GMT):
I knew there was one out there

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:17:50 GMT):
Are you saying there are people that were exploiting the lack of policing?

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:18:39 GMT):
Actually I was saying that the code (perhaps with 6991 it would have been OK) prevents me from using the peer cli to package and install chaincode on my local machine

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:18:53 GMT):
My only argument about that was we never speced that you could load more than just go files in go packages, but we didn't check very carefully and now we do

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:19:41 GMT):
I guess I would have likely been ok with 6991 - my issue was I have multiple projects under my GOPATH

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:19:48 GMT):
I see 6991 as orthogonal to that problem though. 6991 really just eliminates the need to vendor

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:19:57 GMT):
hmmm

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:20:08 GMT):
Ah yeah, wel it fixes that too

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:20:42 GMT):
But it has little to do with adding non golang payloads, which is what Murali was concerned with

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:20:59 GMT):
So yeah - with 6991 I would have never been affected by the file mode / .go file check

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:21:05 GMT):
sure

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:21:18 GMT):
My issue was with the fact of checking file mode

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:21:26 GMT):
Right, but only because it tightens up the payload

mastersingh24 (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:21:28 GMT):
it all goes hand in hand

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:21:33 GMT):
Right

greg.haskins (Tue, 04 Apr 2017 19:22:13 GMT):
After the 6991 stack, the CLI should always generate a pure, minimal golang payload

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 02:09:16 GMT):
still can use eyes on these: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7681/ https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6991/ .... 6991 needs @muralisr approval before merging pls

muralisr (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 02:24:19 GMT):
Was just doing `make testenv` prior to running e2e

muralisr (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 02:24:19 GMT):
Was just doing `make testenv` prior to running e2e @greg.haskins

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 02:59:56 GMT):
heh, ok

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:23:05 GMT):
@harrijk https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7709/

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:23:22 GMT):
i point that out because its a gate that frees up the new baseimage spin

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:23:28 GMT):
(or I would like to get that in first, anyway

harrijk (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:24:04 GMT):
Thanks.

harrijk (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:24:44 GMT):
Any idea on when this might be merged in?

muralisr (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:27:25 GMT):
@greg.haskins added a comment to 7709...`What would this mean to folks (especially developers) who are used to/rely on Vagrant ? Just slower "vagrant up" the first time ?`

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:49:43 GMT):
in theory, its probably slower but I would guess not appreciably so: its all binary installations so as long as you have a decent internet connection...

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:50:00 GMT):
the main advantage is that baseimage meant some of that binary download was cachable

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:50:39 GMT):
whereas this model means the provisioner will re-download some of the tools whenever its rebuilt

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:51:11 GMT):
i think the most important part is that docker-baseimage release be decoupled from vagrant

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:51:35 GMT):
we could achieve that this way, or we could retain a vagrant baseimage that is independent from docker baseimage (at least in release cycle)

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:51:52 GMT):
but until we have automated CI pipelines that can build vagrant, this is very painful for me

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:51:58 GMT):
I have to build/push by hand

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:52:15 GMT):
(the kicker is: we _do_ have this pipeline, it was just flaky)

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:52:43 GMT):
for whatever reason, the LF substrate for running virtualbox jobs was unreliable

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:53:53 GMT):
there are some positives here too I should point out

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:54:17 GMT):
the devenv is decidedly simpler and more transparent now (it all is conrolled more or less by that one script)

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:54:36 GMT):
also, if someone needs a change, they can just mod fabric.git in a standard way

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:55:03 GMT):
right now, baseimage changes have to go through fabric-baseimage.git CR, approval, and then wait for a release window

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:55:18 GMT):
so we do gain some agility

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:56:22 GMT):
but to your point: ill benchmark the before and after

greg.haskins (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 13:56:38 GMT):
(and add that to the commit message)

adc (Wed, 05 Apr 2017 14:38:06 GMT):

muralisr (Fri, 07 Apr 2017 12:15:49 GMT):
next in the series of tasks for chaincode packaging (https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-2859), https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7823/ provides an interface for hiding package details (either the current mode of dumping deployment spec or the using the more sophisticated package container)... with this abstraction we will at last be able to do an actual install of the package container.. please note that we will retain deploying the raw deployment spec (mainly for ease of use ... it will be nice to have only one way in the end upto fabric users to decide)

JonathanLevi (Fri, 07 Apr 2017 14:45:32 GMT):
Amigos, not sure if all of you have noticed the (relatively) recent update to the contribution guidelines: 1. When submitting change requests, we should start our (git/Gerrit) commit messages with the JIRA ticket in square brackets. e.g., *[FAB-8765] Set the boolean flag 'make-it-awesome' to true by default* 2. Gerrit "auto-url"s it for us. See two examples [that were (pseudo-)randomly picked]: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7781 and https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7709 and this also saves us from some URL encoding issues that some of you used to experience when inlining the URL directly, and makes it a lot easier to look at the "table" of CRs and find/pick one by its JIRA ticket number. 3. No need to update already submitted change requests (unless it was submitted without the/a mandatory JIRA ticket). FWIW, Jonathan

JonathanLevi (Fri, 07 Apr 2017 14:45:32 GMT):
Amigos, not sure if all of you have noticed the (relatively) recent update to the contribution guidelines: 1. When submitting change requests, we should start our (git/Gerrit) commit messages with the JIRA ticket in square brackets. e.g., *[FAB-8765] Set the boolean flag 'make-it-awesome' to true by default* 2. Gerrit "auto-url"s it for us. See two examples [that were (pseudo-)randomly picked]: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7781 and https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7709, this also saves us from some URL encoding issues that some of you used to experience when inlining the URL directly, and makes it a lot easier to look at the "table" of CRs and find/pick one by its JIRA ticket number. 3. No need to update already submitted change requests (unless it/they was submitted without the/a mandatory JIRA ticket). FWIW, Jonathan

muralisr (Fri, 07 Apr 2017 14:56:19 GMT):
@JonathanLevi thanks, will do... at some early point I got the impression that without embedding the URL the notification didn't flow...but if its working consistently for others, I was likely wrong

JonathanLevi (Fri, 07 Apr 2017 15:25:24 GMT):
@muralisr To be honest, regarding the JIRA integration - I still didn't crack that... I noted that sometimes the CR/commits are linked, but not always. It got fixed at some point, but I'm not 100% sure. Will check.

yacovm (Sat, 08 Apr 2017 13:49:57 GMT):
why was it required to prefix with 0?

yacovm (Sat, 08 Apr 2017 13:49:57 GMT):
why was it required to prefix with 0? @mastersingh24

mastersingh24 (Sat, 08 Apr 2017 14:09:10 GMT):
For some odd reason which I argued with him about, Saad felt he needed to prefix the serial number of a 0 if it was less than some number of characters (I think because openssl returned serial numbers with a leading zero)

mastersingh24 (Sat, 08 Apr 2017 14:09:10 GMT):
For some odd reason at the time, Saad felt he needed to prefix the serial number of a 0 if it was less than some number of characters (I think because openssl returned serial numbers with a leading zero)

mastersingh24 (Sat, 08 Apr 2017 14:09:30 GMT):
He then changed the logic in a different unrelated changeset which I just caught

yacovm (Sat, 08 Apr 2017 14:10:38 GMT):
you mean openssl command to generate a certificate?

mastersingh24 (Sat, 08 Apr 2017 14:11:18 GMT):
it was actually using openssl to retrieve the serial number and then use it as input to the revoke command

mastersingh24 (Sat, 08 Apr 2017 14:11:40 GMT):
basically openssl to get the info about a certificate

dave.enyeart (Sun, 09 Apr 2017 16:13:26 GMT):
Ledger items for review list continues to grow :( The first one has been split into 3 to meet changeset size recommendations: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7549 (1 of 4) https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7859 (2 of 4) https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7869 (3 of 4) https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7687 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7787 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7255 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7099 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6793

JonathanLevi (Sun, 09 Apr 2017 22:37:21 GMT):
Hi @dave.enyeart, maybe we/you should approach these differently?

JonathanLevi (Sun, 09 Apr 2017 22:39:26 GMT):
I have merged the first one, so that have the the c_db in... It maybe be easier (for you and the reviewers), to first get the "core" stuff in, and only after "build no top of it". Because, otherwise, for example, after each of my merges, you may need to rebase a few (which can/may get frustrating, for you, exponentially ;-))

JonathanLevi (Sun, 09 Apr 2017 22:39:45 GMT):
Hope I helped, will give these some more attention after the next round/iteration.

dave.enyeart (Mon, 10 Apr 2017 00:55:48 GMT):
Thanks @JonathanLevi . We did attempt to structure them that way. The first three parts each deliver a couchdb building block. Part 4 exercises the first three in the fabric logic. The functions are next to each other in the files, therefore there are merge conflicts. Maybe I'm not understanding the advice though. The splitting, dependencies, and exponential rebasing is indeed making this more difficult and time consuming than having a single changeset to cover the new functionality end-to-end (which we would have done in the past). I'm open to learning if there are some tricks to make this easier for all of us. @cbf @chris.elder

muralisr (Mon, 10 Apr 2017 16:27:30 GMT):
just putting some context around https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7843 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7875 and https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7879 ... they are all related to https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-2859.

muralisr (Mon, 10 Apr 2017 16:30:48 GMT):
They key are the following points ``` provide a notion for "packaging a chaincode" keep existing methods work without change (ie, "install" and "instantiate" etc) link instantiated record with the install via a fingerprint (this is perhaps the most interesting) so future chaincode launches do validation add optional ownership signatures to a package. This is primarily for future expansion and usage```

muralisr (Mon, 10 Apr 2017 16:31:54 GMT):
hopefully that summarizes the tasks listed in FAB-2859

muralisr (Mon, 10 Apr 2017 16:33:18 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7843 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7875 and https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7879 would close most of the tasks

yacovm (Tue, 18 Apr 2017 21:36:09 GMT):
I have 2 gossip change sets that @C0rWin has +1ed and are for v1.0 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8075 - this is the first of a series that deals with confidentiality - it's basically only `70` lines of production code and the rest is test code. https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8155/ this adds basic revocation support to gossip, and will be enhanced in the (near) future to be more efficient and less naive.

yacovm (Tue, 18 Apr 2017 21:36:09 GMT):

binhn (Wed, 19 Apr 2017 18:40:33 GMT):
@rjones @cbf why would chris' -2 remains after a new patch pushed https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7853 ? i thought it would wiped out all review ratings

rjones (Wed, 19 Apr 2017 18:41:48 GMT):
@binhn because -2 is sticky. -1...+2 are not sticky

binhn (Wed, 19 Apr 2017 18:42:50 GMT):
ah, good to know :-) i'll use that from now on :grin:

wlahti (Sat, 22 Apr 2017 13:10:05 GMT):
My big CR to update the all the loggers for the peer is ready to go: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8311/ . It touches a lot of files but the majority of them it simply changes `logging.MustGetLogger` to `flogging.MustGetLogger` (and imports the package). Once this is in, updating the log level for modules using regular expressions will be enabled for anything running on the peer (say goodbye to jumping through hoops to turn off gossip logging :laughing:).

jimthematrix (Sun, 23 Apr 2017 20:03:45 GMT):
@adc while adding ACL please keep the SDK in mind because every strengthened check will cause existing SDK end2end test to fail. the tests have been all using the "Members" identities so far (node SDK has been updated to use "Admins" for join-channel) so for instance after 8229 the install chaincode step now needs the org's admin

jimthematrix (Sun, 23 Apr 2017 20:04:31 GMT):
I like how @smithbk does it with https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-2597

@jiangyaoguo we are seeing issues in build nodes and not able to kick off new builds.. As build nodes are offline, your `reverify` triggering a build build but it's in queue..

gennadyl (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:02:43 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8473/ - fix errors from staticcheck

jiangyaoguo (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:10:16 GMT):
@rameshthoomu thanks for your info. will wait

cbf (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:29:07 GMT):
@greg.haskins can you look at https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/7987/ @rameshthoomu addressed your issue, I believe

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:35:12 GMT):
@cbf I still am torn on whether this is the right direction...at some point, I would like to see "fabric-peer" be a super lightweight container for running a peer instance....

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:35:21 GMT):
I think docker makes a poor CLI experience

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:35:28 GMT):
but that said, I understand why this is needed

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:35:52 GMT):
so, if its a stop-gap and we can revisit our CLI deployment strategy for v1.1+, I am happy

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:36:27 GMT):
if docker will continue to be a CLI vehicle, it should probably be something like "fabric-cli" or "fabric-tools"

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:36:32 GMT):
and leave the poor peer alone ;)

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:40:08 GMT):
@cbf thinking more, it would be near trivial to set the stage for this notion

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:40:47 GMT):
we could trivially add "fabric-cli" based on baseimage (so, has golang compiler, etc) and add peer+configtxgen+cryptogen

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:41:01 GMT):
and then someday when we unify the CLI approach, we just do it there

cbf (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:41:13 GMT):
I agree, and the CLI should actually be a separate thing distributed as platform-specific binary

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:41:20 GMT):
yep

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:41:49 GMT):
but as a stop-gap, we could do a docker image but one that is != "fabric-peer"

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:42:11 GMT):
(one of the problems is I never intended "fabric-peer" to be used for anything other than "peer node start"

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:42:32 GMT):
it has no golang compiler (e.g. to be useful as a "peer chaincode" environment), it doesnt have configtxgen, etc etc

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:42:41 GMT):
(and I dont really want it to have all that

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:43:02 GMT):
I wanted it to be a 25MB payload that ran "peer node start" really really well, and that is it

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:44:28 GMT):
i think post v1.0, we can try to collapse "peer [chaincode/channel/node-status]", configtxgen, and cryptogen into one "fabric-cli" type binary, as you said

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:44:46 GMT):
one that is pure go, so it can be easily built/distributed

greg.haskins (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 14:45:03 GMT):
(e.g. no CGO deps, like libltdr

cbf (Mon, 24 Apr 2017 15:27:50 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8341/

JonathanLevi (Mon, 08 May 2017 13:20:52 GMT):
--- All, to make it easier for us (the maintainers, and other reviewers) to review/evaluate/prioritize CRs better... please make sure that the underlying JIRA tickets contain enough motivation, or in one word the *why* - why something is being suggested, requires a change... this is not only something that we going to be more strict about in the coming weeks (certainly more than before) - but it will also help the code/CR submitter to make sure that what one works is needed + gets the appropriate/correct priority and handled in a more timely fashion. Thanks. ---

JonathanLevi (Sun, 14 May 2017 18:45:52 GMT):

rameshthoomu (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:27:14 GMT):
@mastersingh24 @greg.haskins @cbf need your review comments on this patch. This patch has to go to publish fabric binaries from production CI https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8939/

rameshthoomu (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:27:52 GMT):
especially on this https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8939/17/jjb/fabric/include-raw-fabric-push-fabric-binaries.sh

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:28:36 GMT):
@rameshthoomu I will take a look, but I have serious reservations about two things

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:29:37 GMT):
1) using nexus for release artifacts...need to understand the URI planning better, and 2) using the "make release" artifacts as a substitute for real packaging (RPM/DEB/BREW)

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:29:51 GMT):
ill try to review later today

rameshthoomu (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:37:15 GMT):
thanks @greg.haskins

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:38:06 GMT):
@rameshthoomu see my review comment

mastersingh24 (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:38:08 GMT):
@greg.haskins - we can change in the future - but this is the best we have for now and it is a nice way to least make downloadable archives until we get into installers. We were also told that Nexus3 was what we were supposed to use to host "file" based artifacts / archives

mastersingh24 (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:38:28 GMT):
But agree we need to make sure the URIs are simple

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:38:35 GMT):
heres my beef, so if you can talk me off the ledge

mastersingh24 (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:38:42 GMT):
And if need be we should register vanity URLs

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:38:47 GMT):
@greg.haskins while I want a true installer experience, we need to make progress with baby steps

mastersingh24 (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:38:51 GMT):
talk or walk> ;)

mastersingh24 (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:38:51 GMT):
talk or walk? ;)

mastersingh24 (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:38:57 GMT):
just kidding - but could not resist

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:39:07 GMT):
definitely want simple URI scheme

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:39:11 GMT):
I have no general problem with nexus hosting artifacts...as long as we have some planning around the URLs for being stable enough for LTS windows

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:39:17 GMT):
ideally, not ugly either

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:39:22 GMT):
but first step is to eliminate the need to clone and build to run

mastersingh24 (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:39:22 GMT):
exactly

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:39:41 GMT):
I have been planning on moving the hosting of chaintool from GH-releases to nexus, as a matter of fact

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:39:56 GMT):
but chaintool is a different beast from, say, the peer binary

mastersingh24 (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:40:14 GMT):
Right now the only binaries are the tools

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:40:19 GMT):
chaintool is JVM based, peer is compiled

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:40:20 GMT):
right

mastersingh24 (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:40:37 GMT):
We tested all the cross compilation stuff

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:40:37 GMT):
I am concerned that the golang build is not as universal as we really think (thinking of glibc type problems)

mastersingh24 (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:41:11 GMT):
I agree we need to adjust longer term

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:41:20 GMT):
so, are we really sure we can say "this is universal linux" ?

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:41:35 GMT):
maybe it is: I havent investigated closely...but I suspect it is not

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:41:53 GMT):
I bet there is a coupling to the OS it was built on

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:43:00 GMT):
I certainly appreciate the notion of wanting to eliminate the need for building the binaries first, and for baby steps

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:43:12 GMT):
I am primarily concerned that this is a giant cow pattie ;)

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:43:57 GMT):
I also have a ton of experience with packaging software so I am not thinking that the next step is too far away, should the motivation be there to push

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 12:44:13 GMT):
but I have to run to a family thing, ill be online in a bit

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 14:14:35 GMT):
I just looked:

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 14:14:41 GMT):
```$ make release Building release/linux-amd64/bin/configtxgen for linux-amd64 mkdir -p release/linux-amd64/bin CGO_CFLAGS=" " GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 go build -o /home/ghaskins/sandbox/hyperledger/go/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/release/linux-amd64/bin/configtxgen -tags "nopkcs11" -ldflags "-X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.Version=1.0.0-alpha3-snapshot-88c6b1a4 -X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.BaseVersion=0.3.0 -X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.BaseDockerLabel=org.hyperledger.fabric -X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.DockerNamespace=hyperledger -X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.BaseDockerNamespace=hyperledger" github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/configtx/tool/configtxgen Building release/linux-amd64/bin/cryptogen for linux-amd64 mkdir -p release/linux-amd64/bin CGO_CFLAGS=" " GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 go build -o /home/ghaskins/sandbox/hyperledger/go/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/release/linux-amd64/bin/cryptogen -tags "nopkcs11" -ldflags "-X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.Version=1.0.0-alpha3-snapshot-88c6b1a4 -X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.BaseVersion=0.3.0 -X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.BaseDockerLabel=org.hyperledger.fabric -X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.DockerNamespace=hyperledger -X github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/metadata.BaseDockerNamespace=hyperledger" github.com/hyperledger/fabric/common/tools/cryptogen mkdir -p release/linux-amd64/install ghaskins@hyperledger:~/sandbox/hyperledger/go/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric$ ldd release/linux-amd64/bin/cryptogen linux-vdso.so.1 => (0x00007ffe89906000) libpthread.so.0 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpthread.so.0 (0x00007f0305bf4000) libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f030582d000) /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x000056402aef7000)```

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 14:15:00 GMT):
This isn't likely to be completely portable

greg.haskins (Tue, 16 May 2017 14:15:30 GMT):
@mastersingh24 ^^^

scottz (Tue, 16 May 2017 15:15:44 GMT):
The Quality team is putting together a nice CI report display page for automated daily test suite. But first we are desparately looking for love for some "fabric" patch requests for several tools and test placeholders that will feed into the daily test suite report. Several potential contributors are waiting for these, which will enable them to start writing tests, and of course our team is planning to use them to write numerous tests as well as submit some other tools to too. PLEASE can we get some help with these? scottz (Tue, 16 May 2017 15:15:44 GMT):
The Quality team is putting together a nice CI report display page for automated daily test suite. But first we are desparately looking for love for some "fabric" patch requests for several tools and test placeholders that will feed into the daily test suite report. Several potential contributors are waiting for these, which will enable them to start writing tests, and of course our team is planning to use them to write numerous tests as well as submit some other tools to too. PLEASE can we get some help with these? Scott: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9257/ FAB-3880 rename sys testnames and descripts Scott: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9371/ FAB-3932 standardize test names Latitia: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8841/ [FAB-1017] Fix due to code changes Latitia: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8897/ [FAB-969]: Docker compose files Latitia: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8925/ [FAB-3633]: Setup and Teardown environment Latitia: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9131/ [FAB-3753]: Readme for Behave System Tests Latitia: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9237/ [FAB-3846]: Behave test feature file placeholders Latitia: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9163/ [FAB-3507] Chaincode Tests (this is associated with Nishi's changes, below) Nishi: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9311/ [FAB-3791] Script to Test Chaincode_Example03 Nishi: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9315/ [FAB-3796] Script to Test Chaincode_Example04 Nishi: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9319/ [FAB-3797] Script to Test Chaincode_Example05 Nishi: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9321/ [FAB-3792] Script to test marbles02 chaincode Adnan: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9251/ [FAB-3878] Placeholder for Ledger performance tests Ratnakar: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9377/ [FAB-3935] Add README to Balance-transfer sample Dongming: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9261/ [FAB-3559] submit Performance Traffic Engine (PTE) - This is a large one; we talked about having a playback and merging this working PTE tool.

smithbk (Tue, 16 May 2017 16:54:27 GMT):
Pls review: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8975/ - Fix panic in server start

nickgaski (Tue, 16 May 2017 18:28:11 GMT):
@here - I am curious about the status of this CR - https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/8939/ . We seem to be going back and forth in an endless debate regarding the appropriateness of hosting binaries on nexus and the underlying stability of the URL (I am aware that a previous tarball got wiped out). That said, there is a highest priority bug opened against the fact that getting started does not reflect alpha2 and this seems like the most realistic solution at this moment in time. It should be noted that these are only binaries for the two tools and the images will still be derived from Docker Hub. If the aversion to hosting on nexus is truly merited, then can we offer a better alternative?

jeffgarratt (Tue, 16 May 2017 18:31:37 GMT):
@cbf @mastersingh24 @jyellick @kostas Wanted to ask if https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9337/ is good to go?

jyellick (Tue, 16 May 2017 18:32:30 GMT):
Looks good to me, but with @mastersingh24 in wanting to get @cbf's approval first

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 18:40:42 GMT):
done

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 18:41:48 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/fabric-pr-review?msg=dcTCjXjDYAdGne2Di) @nickgaski it was merged, but I am not clear on what the source of the back and forth is

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 18:42:29 GMT):
from my POV, we want to have people be able to download binaries (or have them installed with the likes of homebrew or apt-get

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 18:42:43 GMT):
we don't want people to have to build the software

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 18:43:01 GMT):
I have been saying this consistently since I can't recall

cbf (Tue, 16 May 2017 18:43:24 GMT):
I know we cut corners for the hackfests but IMO, that was a mistake

nickgaski (Tue, 16 May 2017 18:47:47 GMT):
yes I understand and agree. 8939 is not merged as far as I can tell; and as an example I see a response from Greg stating "I have reservations about the appropriateness of this release method." This is simply a tarball that bundles the examples/e2e_cli content and then inputs the binaries from a `make release-all`. The end user does NOT have to build anything, they merely run the download images script and then the subsequent scripts will grab the appropriate binaries for their platform. I am interjecting here because I cannot update getting started until we reach a conclusion on this CR. The end-to-end.rst document was indeed merged, and that is much appreciated as I plan to port nearly all of it into the Getting Started page

cbf (Thu, 18 May 2017 16:15:29 GMT):
@here https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-3109 needs some review. It is a fix to an intermittently failing test. I believe that @yacovm and @C0rWin want it in, certainly we need to fix the intermittent CI failures. However, there are two approaches that we could take. one being simply skip the intermittently failing test for now. This does introduce about 200 LOC in the production code, but also adds lots of test code. Thoughts?

yacovm (Thu, 18 May 2017 16:16:21 GMT):
> It is a fix to an intermittently failing test. This is not the essence of the change set

yacovm (Thu, 18 May 2017 16:16:26 GMT):
The UT is a bonus

yacovm (Thu, 18 May 2017 16:16:26 GMT):
The UT failure fix is a bonus

yacovm (Thu, 18 May 2017 16:18:21 GMT):
This is a fix to a production problem

C0rWin (Thu, 18 May 2017 16:28:47 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/fabric-pr-review?msg=vFG4GMCMLgzd2mXHr) @cbf Test is a side effect, while CR takes care of more serious problem, 200 LOC is fare price for that ;)

yacovm (Thu, 18 May 2017 16:36:06 GMT):
The big picture is- anchor peer "connection" is a 2-phased thing, but the current code has only retry logic in the 1st phase and not in the 2nd. If the first step succeeded and the 2nd failed (as... happens in the unit tests sometimes) the peer is left alone, disconnected from the anchor peer. The change set simply makes this whole thing more robust, that's all.

yacovm (Thu, 18 May 2017 16:36:06 GMT):
The big picture is- connection to an anchor peer is a 2-phased thing, but the current code has only retry logic in the 1st phase and not in the 2nd. If the first step succeeded and the 2nd failed (as... happens in the unit tests sometimes) the peer is left alone, disconnected from the anchor peer. The change set simply makes this whole thing more robust, that's all.

yacovm (Thu, 18 May 2017 16:36:06 GMT):
The big picture is- connection to an anchor peer is a 2-phased thing, but the current code has only retry logic in the 1st phase and not in the 2nd. If the first step succeeded and the 2nd failed (as... happens in the unit tests sometimes) the peer is left alone, disconnected from the anchor peer. The change set simply makes this whole thing more robust, and makes both phases have retry logic. that's all.

Regarding this JIRA - https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-4033 - do we really want people to compile from master branch? Another approach would be `git checkout v1.0.0-alpha2` `make docker` `git checkout master` . Thoughts?

nickgaski (Fri, 19 May 2017 17:34:05 GMT):
Regarding this JIRA - https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-4033 - do we really want people to compile from master branch? Another approach would be `git checkout v1.0.0-alpha2` `make docker` `make release-all` `git checkout master` . Thoughts?

nickgaski (Fri, 19 May 2017 17:34:05 GMT):
Regarding this JIRA - https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-4033 - do we really want people to compile from master branch? Another approach would be `git checkout v1.0.0-alpha2` `make docker` `make release-all` `git checkout master` . Then run the tests from master branch, as this is where the compatible docker-compose scripts live. Thoughts?

mastersingh24 (Fri, 19 May 2017 18:19:17 GMT):
@nickgaski - the e2e in master must always work against master

mastersingh24 (Fri, 19 May 2017 18:20:09 GMT):
for people using the Docker images, as you know - we've put the e2e in the tarball for each platform

mastersingh24 (Fri, 19 May 2017 18:20:51 GMT):
We actually want to remove the doc from the archive as well - as people who just want to download and use fabric should be referring to RTD

mastersingh24 (Fri, 19 May 2017 18:21:33 GMT):
The only people who should be using the scripts in the master repo (or frankly any tag of the repo) are people doing development on fabric

vpaprots (Fri, 19 May 2017 18:31:30 GMT):
@yacovm @mastersingh24 @cbf would appreciate comments on http://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/9441 (I also posted on FAB-3040). There is a lot of copied SW BCCSP code, with insufficient test coverage. My option is either copy even MORE code from SW BCCSP to improve the test coverage, or do as I did. While it looks like a big change (deleted 2k lines), all I did is compose SW BCCSP into PKCS11 BCCSP struct. I believe this is fairly low risk.

vpaprots (Fri, 19 May 2017 18:32:32 GMT):
I would appreciate direction there sooner, before I start adding more tests please.

dolanor (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:18:46 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

dolanor (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:21:54 GMT):
Hello! What is the best way to get a PR merged (except for making it good to merge) ?

dolanor (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:24:00 GMT):
I made a push to gerrit, but except for the bot, nothing happened. I could think that you might lack the time to review all the commits. So if I personally review some other PR, would it help ? (by removing/merging other PRs, and thus, making more bandwidth available for the merger to focus on less tasks)

dolanor (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:24:26 GMT):
Or it wouldn't since I'm a newcomer and not really approved by anyone out there.

cbf (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:42:06 GMT):
@dolanor the maintainers have been pretty much heads down trying to get the release published, and dealing with last minute issues etc

cbf (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:42:46 GMT):
as such, we basically telegraphed that the only CRs that would get attention were relevant to the alpha2 release

cbf (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:44:22 GMT):
now that it is published, we should be returning to BAU for those items that are a) bug fixes that don't yield extensive change b) new tests that don't make extensive changes to production code, and c) those new tests and bug fixes that do make more extensive change to production code, but whcih the maintainers agree should be in the 1.0 release

cbf (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:47:48 GMT):
see bottom of https://wiki.hyperledger.org/projects/fabric/release_exit_criteria

jimthematrix (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:51:34 GMT):
@mastersingh24 @cbf @yacovm @binh

jimthematrix (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:51:34 GMT):
@mastersingh24 @cbf @yacovm @binhn node SDK changes: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/6825/

cbf (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:51:50 GMT):
you rang?

jimthematrix (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:52:29 GMT):
just edited above

jimthematrix (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:53:16 GMT):
this one has been pending for a long time, finally was able to make it work thanks to the work by the CI team (in preparing the CI VMs with SoftHSM)

cbf (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:55:47 GMT):
really need to learn the Curly Principle ;-)

cbf (Mon, 22 May 2017 15:56:20 GMT):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2k1uOqRb0HU

jimthematrix (Mon, 22 May 2017 16:14:09 GMT):
I realized this could be generating some controversy as we are not committing to HSM support in v1.0 (at least for node or java SDKs), the main reason I'd like to keep this in rather than pulling the code out is to use it to test the SDK's API pluggability design.

jimthematrix (Mon, 22 May 2017 16:14:09 GMT):
I realized this could be generating some controversy as we are not committing to HSM support in v1.0 (at least for node or java SDKs), the main reason I'd like to keep this in rather than pulling the code out is to use it to test the SDK's API pluggability design (we'll have both software-based and pkcs11 based implementation of the CryptoSuite API, equivalent to fabric's BCCSP API)

jimthematrix (Mon, 22 May 2017 16:14:44 GMT):
we can mark the implementation "experimental" if needed

jimthematrix (Mon, 22 May 2017 16:15:25 GMT):
the coding was done a long time ago but we have not been able to test it due to lack of support in the CI VMs.

jimthematrix (Mon, 22 May 2017 16:15:41 GMT):
@cbf ^^^

yacovm (Mon, 22 May 2017 16:17:35 GMT):
> to test the SDK's API pluggability design - how?

yacovm (Mon, 22 May 2017 16:17:35 GMT):
> to test the SDK's API pluggability design - how?

yacovm (Mon, 22 May 2017 16:17:35 GMT):
> to test the SDK's API pluggability design - how?
