cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:50:58 GMT):
@here would appreciate some testing of this CR https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9811/

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:51:34 GMT):
have made changes with @tongli to limit unit-test execution to affected packages only

tongli (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:51:35 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:51:57 GMT):
also replaced gocov with go test -cover as it performs much better

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:52:16 GMT):
would especially appreciate windows and linux testing

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:53:27 GMT):
note new target in Makefile 'verify' will only test packages in the scope of the change

yacovm (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:53:49 GMT):
Why would we want CI to run just the packages that changed?

yacovm (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:54:13 GMT):
I think it's an un-necessary risk. What is the gain here? merge CRs faster?

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:54:40 GMT):
two step process - on submit CR, runs subset, on merge will run full pass and we'll revert merged patches that fail full CI

yacovm (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:54:50 GMT):
auto-revert?

yacovm (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:54:53 GMT):
or manual?

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:54:56 GMT):
yes

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:55:31 GMT):
of course, if ppl don't agree, the change is there for local CI passes to be much more efficient

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:56:14 GMT):
this doesn't change the end-to-end and bdd CI jobs

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:56:16 GMT):
just UT

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:56:35 GMT):
actually, this step changes nothing in CI

yacovm (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:56:39 GMT):
yeah but e2e doesn't test anything but the super-optimistic path

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:56:47 GMT):
understood

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:57:17 GMT):
many if not most large OSS projects revert to either a smoke test first pass or something like this

C0rWin (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:57:49 GMT):
IMO it's better to invest effort trying to improve UT, rather to scoping them for CR specific packages

C0rWin (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:58:04 GMT):
like trying to parallelize them

C0rWin (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:58:11 GMT):
remove sleeps

yacovm (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:58:56 GMT):
1) Well if I have package `a` that imports package `b` and calls `b.F()` and now `b.F()` is removed, master is broken until it auto-reverts. 2) Our UTs are still brittle. That means false-negatives, and auto-reverts right?

yacovm (Thu, 25 May 2017 21:59:28 GMT):
@C0rWin I tried parallelizing them, but the minions that run in CI just couldn't handle the load :(

C0rWin (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:00:19 GMT):
:/

C0rWin (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:04:07 GMT):
@cbf will merge of CR-9811 mean we gonna switch to using it in CI?

C0rWin (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:04:20 GMT):
or it will be an option for meanwhile?

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:07:35 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9799/ could use some love

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:07:59 GMT):
@C0rWin it is an option

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:08:31 GMT):
AFAIK, @rameshthoomu has not begun the ci-management changes

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:08:58 GMT):
if this merges, it can be used to speed up local unit-tests

C0rWin (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:08:59 GMT):
well, so worth to merge it and to use for local development

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:09:05 GMT):
and leave at that

C0rWin (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:09:05 GMT):
yeah

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:09:37 GMT):
I would like to do the auto-revert regardless

cbf (Thu, 25 May 2017 22:09:58 GMT):
but I think that we can and should adopt a two phase process

jimthematrix (Fri, 26 May 2017 02:12:03 GMT):
for https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9749/ - trying again to see if anybody would be interested in reviewing and merging, it's been hanging out for 2 days. even though the CR looks big, the net change is really just adding "newDefaultKeyValueStore()" to FabricCAClientImpl. I had to do a bit of code refactoring though, because that class and Client.js end up having quite a few common properties and methods, so I created a comment base class BaseClient.js that both inherit from. about half of the code changes are in tests

yacovm (Fri, 26 May 2017 13:19:41 GMT):
Bug fixes to be reviewed and merged: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9119/ Mutual TLS https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9637/ StateInfo expiration related bug fix https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9753/ identities expiration related bug fix https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9691/ Prevent logging of the entire pull update to the log. In case of blocks - this may blow up the log with binary data. *Lots* of binary data.

I had to do a bit of code refactoring though, because that class and Client.js end up having quite a few common properties and methods, so I created a comment base class BaseClient.js that both inherit from. about half of the code changes are in tests`

cbf (Mon, 29 May 2017 00:20:05 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9871/

cbf (Mon, 29 May 2017 00:21:28 GMT):
@jimthematrix https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-4131 is review-needed

cbf (Mon, 29 May 2017 00:22:11 GMT):
the point of that was - as the maintainers agreed - to limit changes to production code and to have a process for reviewing and agreeing on substantive changes

cbf (Mon, 29 May 2017 00:25:27 GMT):
the reason that this has not been merged is the same as for @muralisr request for https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9645/ and that is that despite the fact that I have sent DAILY reminders to the #fabric-maintainers list, most of the issues in the https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/Dashboard.jspa?selectPageId=10104#Filter-Results/10517 dashboard list have NOT been reviewed. The idea was to get FIVE mintainers to agree on merging patches that met the criteria we agreed upon and as documented in the wiki https://wiki.hyperledger.org/projects/fabric/release_exit_criteria

jimthematrix (Mon, 29 May 2017 02:49:30 GMT):

yacovm (Mon, 29 May 2017 17:03:50 GMT):
@mastersingh24 is that a planned thing to remove the testchainid? I'm asking because it belongs to category (3)

yacovm (Mon, 29 May 2017 17:05:56 GMT):

mastersingh24 (Mon, 29 May 2017 17:49:19 GMT):
I had opened it as a bug before alpha2 since IMHO it's a bug that this has stayed in the code path. The other "smaller" change would be to set the default to "false" rather than"true" but I think it's both a bug and a security hole to have test code enabled in the production path.

yacovm (Mon, 29 May 2017 17:50:08 GMT):
mm, then it's category (2) then and not (3) right?

yacovm (Mon, 29 May 2017 17:50:08 GMT):
mm, then it's category (2) then and not (3) right @mastersingh24 ?

mastersingh24 (Mon, 29 May 2017 17:57:35 GMT):

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:46:02 GMT):
@mastersingh24 https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9895... removing `--peer-defaultchain=false` will make it use "testchainid" (unless something changed)

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:46:10 GMT):
is that what you are going after ?

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:47:14 GMT):
could be given the compose files are not the usual "e2e" or other known culprits that use channel... just making sure

yacovm (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:48:03 GMT):
@muralisr see https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9887/

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:48:25 GMT):
ah it has been removed

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:48:26 GMT):
ok

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:52:25 GMT):
I've been a bit behind (working on chaincode/ UT :-) )

mastersingh24 (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:53:59 GMT):
@muralisr - for a variety of "odd" reasons, in order to eliminate --peer-defaultchain, I had to do the following: 1) Remove the actual code which creates testchainid from the peer but leave the CLI flag in place so that e2e would pass (since the Java and Node e2e pass --peer-defaultchain=false to the peer on startup) 2) Modify the compose files for e2e for Node and Java to remove the --peer-defaultchain flag 3) Submit a final change which removes the flag from the peer (the trick is that for odd reasons, the SDK e2e's will fail if testchainid is created on startup)

mastersingh24 (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:54:38 GMT):
Rick merged the Java change yesterday (before we realized all of the complex dependencies :( )

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:55:37 GMT):
ok. will stay away a bit then :-) ... but this is nice!

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:55:43 GMT):
talking of nice...

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:56:14 GMT):
I have made very good progress with chaincode UT ...65% coverage without spinning a single image or starting peer

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:57:16 GMT):
but really could do some help with https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-3948 please

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:57:33 GMT):
I'd need common mockpeer changes for the chaincode work

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:58:11 GMT):
I *could* refactor https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/9645/ to remove all the error handling refactoring

muralisr (Mon, 29 May 2017 22:58:20 GMT):
but its not all that bad

mastersingh24 (Fri, 02 Jun 2017 19:15:05 GMT):
@cbf - is this what is going to be run in CI as well? It's not hard to just test your own changes locally today - I do it all the time. But I worry that it's risky to change how we test this close to a potential release. I also know that I missed part of the debate on this earlier

cbf (Fri, 02 Jun 2017 19:16:03 GMT):
@mastersingh24 no, CI won't change until we have an ability to run a full CI pass between reviews and merge

cbf (Fri, 02 Jun 2017 19:16:19 GMT):
this will ONLY affect LOCAL builds

cbf (Fri, 02 Jun 2017 19:16:46 GMT):
there is a new target 'make desk-check' and another 'make verify' that will exploit the changes

cbf (Fri, 02 Jun 2017 19:16:46 GMT):
there are new targets 'make desk-check' and another 'make verify' that will exploit the changes

cbf (Fri, 02 Jun 2017 19:17:50 GMT):
as for testing your own changes, you have to manually enter the TEST_PKGS variable and it still uses gocov which is slow as molasses

cbf (Fri, 02 Jun 2017 19:18:29 GMT):
the new targets use go test -cover which for a full pass can reduce the UT overhead from about an hour to 40 minutes

jyellick (Fri, 02 Jun 2017 20:24:54 GMT):

muralisr (Thu, 29 Jun 2017 22:44:16 GMT):
@rjones @cbf @rameshthoomu I think it is this line 305 (in my env) in Makefile that's the cause of this `release/%: GO_LDFLAGS=-X $(pkgmap.$(@F))/metadata.Version=$(PROJECT_VERSION)` `

muralisr (Thu, 29 Jun 2017 22:44:16 GMT):
@rjones @cbf @rameshthoomu I think it is this line 305 (in my env) in Makefile that's the cause of this `release/%: GO_LDFLAGS=-X $(pkgmap.$(@F))/metadata.Version=$(PROJECT_VERSION) `

muralisr (Thu, 29 Jun 2017 22:45:44 GMT):
commenting that out, make clean and make dist (and release etc) seems to fix it... but need @greg.haskins eyes

muralisr (Thu, 29 Jun 2017 22:45:44 GMT):
commenting that out, make clean and make dist (and release etc) seems to fix `peer version`... but need @greg.haskins eyes

muralisr (Thu, 29 Jun 2017 22:45:44 GMT):
commenting that out, make clean and make dist (and release etc) seems to fix `peer version`... but need @greg.haskins eyes. The problem appears to be that peer and rest of the binaries follow different rules for metadata pattern. Line 305 does the the right thing for other binaries except for the peer binary

greg.haskins (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 11:31:11 GMT):
Oh man, I am not sure how all those DRY violations crept in, heh

cbf (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 11:43:28 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/11245/

muralisr (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 11:46:23 GMT):
@greg.haskins the right fix would be fix metadata so all bins will follow the same pattern but that seemed too drastic at this stage

muralisr (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 11:48:09 GMT):
also we could override GO_LDFLAGS just in the peer production and leave the `release/%` rule in ...but I thought making the dependency explicit in each of the production is OK too

greg.haskins (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 12:01:55 GMT):
@muralisr sorry, that wasnt directed at you

greg.haskins (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 12:02:32 GMT):
I understand what you are trying to do...i was more lamenting on how the Makefile:release targets proliferated like that to begin with

greg.haskins (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 12:03:35 GMT):
first and foremost, those rules should be refactored so its not repeating itself...second thought is, the release process might deserve its own subordinate makefile at this point

greg.haskins (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 12:03:41 GMT):
neither here nor there on your patch though

cbf (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 12:04:11 GMT):
that was me, because it was easier to brute force than slog through a complete revamp of the makefile;-)

cbf (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 12:04:34 GMT):
we do need to do that... lots of targets with circular dependencies

greg.haskins (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 12:05:14 GMT):
no worries..i can take a look at it at some point

greg.haskins (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 12:05:27 GMT):
just looks a bit off the rails, but maybe there is nuance I am missing

nickgaski (Fri, 30 Jun 2017 13:42:31 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/11205/ - this is an expansion on some work from Chris. It removes go source from each subdirectory in fabric samples and places into a central `chaincode` folder. Also allows the fabcar sample to leverage the basic-network docker-compose and the existing crypto/artifacts present in that directory

jyellick (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 17:55:12 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/11645/ <- This is a bug fix which should definitely go into v1.0.1

cbf (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:23:01 GMT):
I agree, but help me understand how this would break existing deployments?

cbf (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:23:12 GMT):
@jyellick ^^

jyellick (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:25:05 GMT):
The CR does _not_ break anyone. If we made some other changes, it could. If we simply converted that `Warning` into an error, then anyone who has an infrastructure based on the old `configtxgen` will not be able to create channels until they update their version of `configtxgen` to match their update fabric.

cbf (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:25:59 GMT):
which seems like a good thing, no?

cbf (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:26:40 GMT):
ie this is a problem, why not get them to upgrade both fabric and configtxgen?

cbf (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:27:19 GMT):
and presume that use of new configtxgen could be used with 1.0.0 fabric

jyellick (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:27:41 GMT):
If we agree it is okay to require `configtxgen` and `fabric` to be upgraded together, then I am happy to change this into an error. I was simply err-ing on the side of not breaking things until we had more strict guidelines on what level of breakage is allowed in v1.0.1

cbf (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:29:30 GMT):
just to be clear the fixed configtxgen will work with 1.0.0 fabric without issue, use of the old configtxgen with fabric 1.0.1 would disallow creation of channels

cbf (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:29:47 GMT):
and force an update of configtxgen, yes?

cbf (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:30:24 GMT):
if so, seems like changing the warning to an error is desirable

yacovm (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:39:19 GMT):
IIRC Gari added a `--version` flag to all binaries, no?

yacovm (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:39:32 GMT):
I think this can be used to distinguish the configtxgen binaries

yacovm (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:41:47 GMT):
``` configtxgen: Version: 1.0.1-snapshot-d9c3202 ``` vs ``` configtxgen: Version: 1.0.0-rc2-snapshot-4709b33 ```

yacovm (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 19:42:17 GMT):
At least the end user doesn't need to "guess" what version its binary is now

cbf (Fri, 14 Jul 2017 20:30:33 GMT):
correct

We need to get them merged somehow.

scottz (Thu, 20 Jul 2017 19:11:58 GMT):
^^^ help please: @mastersingh24 @dave.enyeart @muralisr @yacovm @jyellick @binhn @JonathanLevi and any other available folks: these are behave scripts, plus some include a bit of python - mostly that copy and modify existing functions and constructs so you should not require in-depth python expertise. We need to get them merged somehow.

scottz (Thu, 20 Jul 2017 19:22:37 GMT):
Since there are few maintainers with the necessary language expertise, and since they are mostly focused on the dev effort rather than the system test automation efforts, could we drum up some more interest among current maintainers to agree to add 1 or 2 other maintainers with the interest and skillset to focus on the test CRs?

jyellick (Thu, 20 Jul 2017 19:34:38 GMT):
I'd feel better if @jeffgarratt gave a thumbs on up these CRs before processing as he understands the behave best

Ratnakar (Thu, 20 Jul 2017 20:10:05 GMT):
As per discussions with @kostas , updated e2e_cli scripts to include kafka ordereing service. https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/11789

mastersingh24 (Thu, 20 Jul 2017 20:46:34 GMT):
[You should propose creating separate repository for this stuff. Other than the core BDD, not sure why this would belong in the fabric repo ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/fabric-pr-review?msg=KZmYpSabzP8EK22SQ) @scottz

scottz (Thu, 20 Jul 2017 20:52:40 GMT):
hmmm. That idea definitely merits further consideration.

latitiah (Thu, 20 Jul 2017 21:29:15 GMT):
We've discussed doing this a few months ago and were told to move to a different directory instead, which we did. I'm all for moving this to a different repo, but we need a decision so we can move forward.

scottz (Fri, 21 Jul 2017 16:58:42 GMT):
@mastersingh24 Latitia is remembering some conversations we had with @cbf and a couple others, some time ago, when it was suggested and decided to put system test tools and automation testcases under fabric/test/ (instead of putting them under fabric/bddtest/ with jeff's bdd, or creating a new repo such as fabric-test). One reason was to keep the code together with the tests that were to be used in daily automation - and in effect encourage people to find the tools and write more tests. It has become abundantly clear that we will need to add some testers as maintainers - whether we continue to use fabric/test/ or whether we create a new repo. I could put together a summary and send proposal to the distribution list. It would make sense to request a vote. I would ask folks to provide other experiences and insights. And I would ask them to either agree to add testers as fabric mainainers or to create a new repo (with the accompanying overhead and lack of co-location with fabric code).

jimthematrix (Fri, 21 Jul 2017 18:44:27 GMT):

JonathanLevi (Thu, 03 Aug 2017 19:20:45 GMT):
Hi @dsanchezseco

JonathanLevi (Thu, 03 Aug 2017 19:21:55 GMT):
Thanks for the second CR. Just to quickly point out that if you are adding a new file to Hyperledger (under Apache 2.0) that is yours... you can still retain the copyrights.

JonathanLevi (Thu, 03 Aug 2017 19:22:13 GMT):
You don't have to assign it to IBM Corp., or anyone else.

JonathanLevi (Thu, 03 Aug 2017 19:22:37 GMT):
Here, for example: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/12133/1/chaincode/chaincode_history/chaincode_history_test.go

grapebaba (Fri, 04 Aug 2017 02:14:01 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/11933/ hope more experts to review

dsanchezseco (Fri, 04 Aug 2017 06:23:24 GMT):
@JonathanLevi i didnt thought of it. What about if the code it's mostly based on some code already available on the repo, even though the files are new(as is the case here, the code is 90% chaincode_example02 and the rest to execute it)? I've just add it some code.

JonathanLevi (Fri, 04 Aug 2017 06:25:04 GMT):
While I am not a legal expert (un?)fortunately... that's fair enough - if you are building on existing copyrighted material, then it make sense (to me) to keep the original copyright... especially if you don't mind.

dsanchezseco (Fri, 04 Aug 2017 06:26:36 GMT):
Yeah, it's not that elaborated to claim ownership of it hahahahaha

JonathanLevi (Fri, 04 Aug 2017 06:27:06 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/fabric-pr-review?msg=zXdwtg6MRpN9NEN3e) The main point I wanted to make, in general, is this (for future work that you do, etc. Feel free to "own" stuff that's yours. Apache 2.0 is really nice in this sense...

JonathanLevi (Fri, 04 Aug 2017 06:27:34 GMT):
Sure, sure. Having fun coding is more important, I know exactly what you mean ;-)

aleksandar.likic (Thu, 17 Aug 2017 17:33:41 GMT):
Hi, this CR is ready for review: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/12435/. Notice that the 'behave' part of the build is currently failing because a change to CI is needed and has to be made together with the code change, but the CI change has been verified by Ramesh Babu (see his comment on Patch Set 2) and the agreement with him is that he'll make a simple change to CI at the time the change is merged. This is adding to fabric an ability to distribute precompiled chaincode in binary form. See https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-5460. The design document is at https://docs.google.com/document/d/1kTkZEEaIB6tQJTQtWzx1YH2zR1O2PwrRhIVpTSUpLiQ/edit#heading=h.9pacqguezrqe. Thanks!

adc (Wed, 23 Aug 2017 00:44:26 GMT):
Hi All, is it possible to vendor packages with MIT license?

jyellick (Wed, 23 Aug 2017 01:11:13 GMT):
@adc Looks like it is okay https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-a

jyellick (Wed, 23 Aug 2017 01:11:13 GMT):
@adc Looks like MIT is okay https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-a And FYI here is a list which is not okay: https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-x there has been a discussion recently on the TSC list especially about the BSD+patents license from Facebook for React JS which is prohibited.

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 14:51:34 GMT):
hi gari

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 14:51:44 GMT):
well, keith already came up with a couple of comments

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 14:52:42 GMT):
@smithbk I was using closeDB and you suggested Clean :)

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 14:53:24 GMT):
I thought your point about being the pendant of Init was good so I changed

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 14:53:24 GMT):
I thought your point about being the opposite (?) of Init was good so I changed

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 14:54:34 GMT):
but that's minor

smithbk (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 14:54:57 GMT):
yeh, but as I looked closer, I didn't think it was doing the opposite of Init as it doesn't delete the generate crypto

smithbk (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 14:54:57 GMT):
yeh, but as I looked closer, I didn't think it was doing the opposite of Init as it doesn't delete the generated crypto

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 14:55:14 GMT):
indeed

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:00:21 GMT):
@smithbk I see your point about moving the call to serve

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:01:38 GMT):
how do I suggest I treat the errors though? serve returns the http.Serve error

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:01:38 GMT):
how do you suggest I treat the errors though? serve returns the http.Serve error

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:02:54 GMT):
you don't treat the error returned by closeListener

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:03:00 GMT):
so I could do the same

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:03:41 GMT):
but that strategy hasn't always worked so I prefer to ask ;-)

smithbk (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:04:16 GMT):
I think just logging it is sufficient

smithbk (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:06:22 GMT):
And if there was not another error, you could also return the db close error ... but would not override an existing error

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:07:20 GMT):
ok

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:12:05 GMT):
regarding whether it should be public or not, the problem is that if one calls Init and not Start, then CloseDB must be called explicitly because you can't call Stop to get it done

smithbk (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:14:15 GMT):
hmm ... Init shouldn't leave the DB open

smithbk (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:14:15 GMT):
hmm ... Init shouldn't leave the DB open ... checking

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:14:38 GMT):
really?

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:15:35 GMT):
then the bug is different than what I understood

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:16:03 GMT):
I thought Init opens the db and needs to leave it open until the server is done

smithbk (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:17:01 GMT):
No, the purpose of Init is to create the crypto material without starting the server and is a complete operation

smithbk (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:17:11 GMT):
or should have been :-)

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:17:18 GMT):
I see :)

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:17:28 GMT):
ok, let me have another look at this then

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:18:13 GMT):
closing the db at the end of Init would certainly simplify things

smithbk (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:18:51 GMT):
yes, that is what it should be doing ... but doing it at the end of serve is also needed as you were doing

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:19:04 GMT):
yes, I realize that

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:19:41 GMT):

so, let me take another pass at it

lehors (Mon, 28 Aug 2017 15:19:50 GMT):

vukolic (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 08:02:41 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

vukolic (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 08:06:19 GMT):
Hi all https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/12849/ is a performance-critical patch that addresses the current performance bottleneck in Fabric 1.0.1 - we would like to see it in 1.1. It fixes the issue described in https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-5932 @mastersingh24 @yacovm @binhn @kostas @jyellick

yacovm (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 08:14:03 GMT):
@vukolic : 1) We must wait until @aso removes the WIP tag before it can be considered merge-able 2) What about pipelining? I think it's worth to have a pipeline that in the 1st part of the pipeline it does validation (CPU intensive) and in the 2nd part it does the commit (which is more IO intensive, since you write to the disk). When the validation of a block finishes, it is passed to the commit and then the CPU is free to do validation of the next block. 3) I think we must be careful not to over-commit the CPU with validation, because other components of the peer need the CPU (i.e gossip also uses validation of messages, and if you steal too many CPU cycles we'll start dropping blocks)

vukolic (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 08:16:54 GMT):
1) ack @aso 2) pipelining can be added orthogonally to this (and later on - it might complicate the CR to do it now) 3) number of goroutines in the threadpool is defaulted to 128*CPU which is certainly much less than go supports but seems sufficient to cover all txs in parallel in a majority of cases. The 128 is a configurable param.

vukolic (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 08:16:54 GMT):
1) ack @aso 2) pipelining can be added orthogonally to this (and later on - it might complicate the CR to do it now) 3) number of goroutines in the threadpool is defaulted to 128*#CPU which is certainly much less than go supports but seems sufficient to cover all txs in parallel in a majority of cases. The 128 is a configurable param.

yacovm (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 08:23:18 GMT):
3 - yeah, I'm just worried that would steal much CPU cycles from other CPU intensive code paths that the peer does. I guess the best way would be to simply evaluate

aso (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 08:54:02 GMT):
@vukolic @yacovm I've removed the WIP tag

aso (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 08:54:18 GMT):
re 2 -> I'm working on pipelining, that's a great idea

aso (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 08:54:32 GMT):
I think we can stage changes by letting this one in first and adding pipelining later, wdyt?

aso (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 08:55:15 GMT):
re 3 -> @yacovm if you think we should default to a smaller number, pls let me know, I'd be happy to change it. We picked 128 x NCPUs to maximize validator throughput

yacovm (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 09:14:15 GMT):
Of course, your change set is hard to review even now, no need to make it more complex

yacovm (Tue, 29 Aug 2017 09:14:22 GMT):
:wink:

dileban (Mon, 11 Sep 2017 04:50:23 GMT):

dileban (Mon, 11 Sep 2017 04:54:33 GMT):
Noticed a few typos in the documentation as I was reading through and thought I'd fix these and submit them. I've read through the contribution material as well as the documentation README for fabric. Could someone comment on these before I do anything: - When I create an issue on Jira, do I need to wait for a maintainer to respond before I could submit the fix for the documentation? - Whom do I list as reviewers? I can find a list of maintainers but not reviewers, are these the same people and can I pick two randomly?

yacovm (Mon, 11 Sep 2017 06:44:39 GMT):
@dileban > - When I create an issue on Jira, do I need to wait for a maintainer to respond before I could submit the fix for the documentation? No. Worst case the change will get comments and you'll need to fix something. > - Whom do I list as reviewers? I can find a list of maintainers but not reviewers, are these the same people and can I pick two randomly? The reviewers are everyone you want to review your change set. It won't get merged without maintainer votes, and you don't have to add maintainers as reviewers, although that helps to make them notice your change set.

dileban (Mon, 11 Sep 2017 08:37:50 GMT):
Thansk @yacovm

mathiasb303 (Mon, 11 Sep 2017 09:09:21 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

jyellick (Mon, 11 Sep 2017 15:31:26 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/12533/2/common/viperutil/config_util.go@320 Some other opinions would be appreciated. In summary, we use moderately strict viper parsing today, but there is a sort of 'fuzzy' parsing that can be turned on for viper which does some nice conversions automatically (like converting bool values naturally), but it comes with some other esoteric behavior which might be less desirable. I'm on the fence about whether turning it on is a good idea or not

mastersingh24 (Mon, 11 Sep 2017 20:06:20 GMT):

dileban (Wed, 13 Sep 2017 03:11:09 GMT):
Improvement to documentation: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/13391/ Quick newbie question: do I need to set the Jira issue status to 'In Review' or does the proper workflow require the reviewers to do this?

jyellick (Wed, 13 Sep 2017 03:36:16 GMT):
@dileban You should set the status to "In Review" yourself. The maintainer's should handle setting it to "Done" when merged.

dileban (Wed, 13 Sep 2017 04:09:06 GMT):
Thansk @jyellick. I also didn't specify a sprint for the issue on Jira because this would have impacted the time line (Even though I submitted a fix)

jyellick (Wed, 13 Sep 2017 04:24:33 GMT):
You should be good to ignore the sprint field, this won't have any negative affect.

jyellick (Wed, 13 Sep 2017 04:24:33 GMT):
You should be good to ignore the sprint field, this won't have any negative effect.

dileban (Wed, 13 Sep 2017 04:27:53 GMT):
Cool. One last question. Should I see a link from the Jira issue to the Gerrit changeset?

jyellick (Wed, 13 Sep 2017 04:35:27 GMT):
The link is only created on merge. To help those sorting through the JIRA issue's it's appreciated if you add a comment linking to the in review CR when you move the JIRA to "In Review".

jyellick (Wed, 13 Sep 2017 04:35:27 GMT):
The link is only created on merge. To help those sorting through the JIRA issues it's appreciated if you add a comment linking to the in review CR when you move the JIRA to "In Review".

jyellick (Wed, 13 Sep 2017 04:35:27 GMT):
The link is only created on merge. To help those sorting through the JIRA issues it's appreciated if you add a comment linking to the in review CR when you move the JIRA status to "In Review".

jyellick (Wed, 13 Sep 2017 04:35:27 GMT):
The link is only created automatically on merge. To help those sorting through the JIRA issues it's appreciated if you add a comment linking to the in review CR when you move the JIRA status to "In Review".

lehors (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:27:05 GMT):

lehors (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:27:50 GMT):
@mastersingh24 Gari? :-)

JonathanLevi (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:38:23 GMT):
Hi @lehors

lehors (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:38:40 GMT):
hi!

JonathanLevi (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:38:48 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/11639/13/lib/server.go

JonathanLevi (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:39:37 GMT):
Just to check, with the new implementation, do you prefer to call *err2 := s.closeDB()* even in case you already have an *err* ?

lehors (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:40:33 GMT):
yes, because I want to return err - the original error

lehors (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:41:15 GMT):
that's the root cause the user would primarily want to be aware off

lehors (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:41:48 GMT):
if there is also an error while closing the db it's secondary

JonathanLevi (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:43:10 GMT):
The issue with doing something like... *err = s.init(renew)* *if err !=nil* { err2 := s.closeDB() if err2!=nil { log. } ... return err; }

JonathanLevi (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:43:42 GMT):
Is that you'd still want to call *s.closeDB()* in case of an error, right?

JonathanLevi (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:43:42 GMT):
Is that you'd still want to call *s.closeDB()* in case of an error (*err*), right?

JonathanLevi (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:43:42 GMT):
Is that you'd still want to call *s.closeDB()* in case of an error ( *err* ), right?

lehors (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:44:05 GMT):
that's what it does

JonathanLevi (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:44:14 GMT):
Yup, cool. Just checking.

JonathanLevi (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:44:14 GMT):
Yup, cool. Thanks for confirming.

JonathanLevi (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:45:19 GMT):
Thank you. Merged.

yacovm (Mon, 25 Sep 2017 09:51:21 GMT):

It's a pretty critical fix (for https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-6294)

aleksandar.likic (Wed, 27 Sep 2017 22:46:16 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/13851/ (https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-6317) Split the peer into the server and the client part. The peer binary is still the server, and all client functions have been moved into the new fabriccli binary. This change enables having different build strategies for the server and the client (for example dynamic vs static build, which is important for things like go plugin and PKCS11 support). Also, this change is (hopefully) a step towards refactoring the fabric code so the fabric client protos and supporting libraries are detached from the server code. This way, the client API could be used by fabriccli and Go SDK (and potentially other Go based fabric client software) without having to depend on the whole fabric that includes the server code. Please propose another name for the fabric client binary if you don't find fabriccli suitable.

aleksandar.likic (Wed, 27 Sep 2017 22:46:16 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/13851/ (https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-6317) Split the peer into the server and the client part. The peer binary is still the server, and all client functions have been moved into the new fabriccli binary. This change enables having different build strategies for the server and the client (for example dynamic vs static build, which is important for things like go plugin and PKCS11 support). Also, this change is (hopefully) a step towards refactoring the fabric code so the fabric client protos and supporting libraries are decoupled from the server code. This way, the client API could be used by fabriccli and Go SDK (and potentially other Go based fabric client software) without having to depend on the whole fabric that includes the server code. Please propose another name for the fabric client binary if you don't find fabriccli suitable.

aleksandar.likic (Wed, 27 Sep 2017 22:46:16 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/13851/ (https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-6317) Split the peer into the server and the client part. The peer binary is still the server, and all client functions have been moved into the new fabriccli binary. This change enables having different build strategies for the server and the client (for example dynamic vs static build, which is important for things like support for go plugins and PKCS11). Also, this change is (hopefully) a step towards refactoring the fabric code so the fabric client protos and supporting libraries are decoupled from the server code. This way, the client API could be used by fabriccli and Go SDK (and potentially other Go based fabric client software) without having to depend on the whole fabric that includes the server code. Please propose another name for the fabric client binary if you don't find fabriccli suitable.

scottz (Fri, 20 Oct 2017 15:33:53 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/fabric-pr-review?msg=sgNSjEBn6idLwW6JQ) @rameshthoomu Our smoke tests ensure: - protobufs accessible from our test environment - can override config env vars - can bring up networks with a channel and example02 chaincode and do invoke and query - with and without TLS - with GO chaincode and NODE chaincode - with solo and kafka - with levelDB and couchDB

scottz (Fri, 20 Oct 2017 15:33:53 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/fabric-pr-review?msg=sgNSjEBn6idLwW6JQ) @rameshthoomu Our smoke tests get latest commits from fabric-test, fabric, fabric-ca, fabric-sdk-node, cello, and ensure the following (on single platform, but later could integrate cello and remote multiple hosts): - protobufs accessible from our test environment - can override config env vars - can bring up networks with a channel and example02 chaincode and do invoke and query - with and without TLS - with GO chaincode and NODE chaincode - with solo and kafka - with levelDB and couchDB

nnao (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:27:54 GMT):
Please review this https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/15737/ There is a deadlock between fabric and sdk-node. To merge the patches for fabric, it needs to change the test to accept return code 404 in sdk-node(fabric-e2e test executes sdk-node test). To get prepared for the change of test in sdk-node, it needs to change fabric. How can I fix this deadlock?

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:31:20 GMT):
I guess you modify the SDK to support both

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:31:27 GMT):
then re-build the fabric

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:31:27 GMT):
then re-build the fabric change set

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:31:38 GMT):
then re-program the SDK to support only 1

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:31:42 GMT):
@nnao ^

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:32:37 GMT):
but to me, this looks like a fairly large change for the SDK no?

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:32:37 GMT):
but to me, this looks like a fairly large change for the SDK

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:32:46 GMT):
it impacts all of error handling in node.js and in java no?

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:32:46 GMT):
it impacts all of error handling in node.js and in java,

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:32:55 GMT):
because the SDK uses promises and the java uses exceptions

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:33:04 GMT):
this looks to me like a huge amount of code change, no?

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:33:45 GMT):
by the way - I think your CR is what should have been done long, long ago, in the first place

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:34:20 GMT):
not sure how to proceed at this point though, because it seems like this would make a v1.0 peer be unable to interop with a v1.1 SDK

yacovm (Fri, 08 Dec 2017 18:36:37 GMT):
maybe @muralisr and @jimthematrix can take a look since it is related to their fields (chaincode and SDK)

muralisr (Thu, 04 Jan 2018 21:16:48 GMT):
muralisr 4:10 PM just saw Jeff's comment, will address on the CR but the bottomline is that the FSM wasn't doing anything except add indirection (channel messages to move from ready -> ready state for most part after handshake). The first CR just removes the FSM. dave.enyeart 4:11 PM I am for FSM removal...better sooner than later in my opinion. We still have a lot of system test ahead of us in 1.1 shutdown, over the course of alpha, beta, GA testing. muralisr 4:13 PM but @jeffgarratt comment `I do not think this makes the code any simpler, but reduces the ability to comprehend the state changes which still remain.` really is addressed by the CRs on top which basically say that there is just handshake followed by "ready" we needed a lot of states in 0.5 to handle serialization of "invokes" while "queries" can be concurrent I wish we had time to remove FSM along with 1.0 when it remove the need for serialization but we left the FSM in (1) reduce the changes and (2) didn't want to rock the boat too much while making sure the concurrency worked correctly the FSM just now just adds more core and increases path length (via channel messages etc) for no good reason dave.enyeart 4:16 PM @muralisr Jonathan has moved the conversation over to fabric-pr-review. Let's copy our comments there 🙂 muralisr 4:16 PM just look at the amount of code removed

dave.enyeart (Thu, 04 Jan 2018 21:16:51 GMT):
I am in favor of FSM removal...better sooner than later in my opinion. We still have a lot of system test ahead of us in 1.1 shutdown, over the course of alpha, beta, GA testing. Doing it later will only add more risk.

muralisr (Thu, 04 Jan 2018 21:17:22 GMT):
hey @jeffgarratt ^^^ (happy new year btw ! :-) )

muralisr (Thu, 04 Jan 2018 21:19:36 GMT):
I think if you look at all the 3 CRs together you'll see the rationale

rameshthoomu (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 20:41:01 GMT):
Need review on this please https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/16715/ (upgrading node version `8.9.1` in fabric baseimage)

smithbk (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 21:21:04 GMT):
Any reason for not using 8.9.4?

smithbk (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 21:21:09 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/16715/

smithbk (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 21:21:09 GMT):
https://nodejs.org/download/release/v8.9.4/

rameshthoomu (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 22:08:13 GMT):
@smithbk not sure patch is based on the FAB-6770

rameshthoomu (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 22:12:07 GMT):
I think it's make sense to test and upgrade to `8.9.4`. @bretharrison @davidkel inputs pls?

bretharrison (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 22:20:05 GMT):
Yes, I would like to run with 8.9.4 for bit before upgrade

bretharrison (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 22:20:05 GMT):
Yes, I would like to run with 8.9.4 for a bit before upgrade

davidkel (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 22:35:49 GMT):
@rameshthoomu The Jira only presented an example of a version at the time of writing (and was not requesting that specific version). In fact I would expect the Jira to always remain open as a driver to ensure that when a release of fabric is to be done, a check is made to determine the versions of node available with a view to upgrade and see if any breaking problems on the latest release which might stop using that version. So in this case 8.9.4 is the latest version of node available, are there any breaking problems in it and as such is not a good candidate to go with. If for any reason it isn't a safe choice then check the previous micro release version.

davidkel (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 22:35:49 GMT):
@rameshthoomu The Jira only presented an example of a version at the time of writing (and was not requesting that specific version). In fact I would expect the Jira to always remain open as a driver to ensure that when a release of fabric is to be done, a check is made to determine the versions of node available with a view to upgrade and see if any breaking problems on the latest release which might stop using that version. So in this case 8.9.4 is the latest version of node available, are there any breaking problems in it and as such is not a good candidate to go with. If for any reason it isn't a safe choice then check the previous micro release version etc

davidkel (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 22:42:32 GMT):
Our builds always run with the latest LTS version and that is 8.9.4 as of now and we've not seen any problems

davidkel (Fri, 12 Jan 2018 22:42:32 GMT):
Our builds always run with the latest LTS version and that is 8.9.4 as of now and we've not seen any problems and I've not heard of any breaking issues with this version so it would seem to be good release to upgrade to

baohua (Sat, 13 Jan 2018 05:42:54 GMT):

lehors (Mon, 15 Jan 2018 14:32:37 GMT):

lehors (Mon, 15 Jan 2018 14:33:10 GMT):

lehors (Mon, 15 Jan 2018 14:35:55 GMT):

lehors (Mon, 15 Jan 2018 14:36:25 GMT):
yet they tend to be simply ignored for weeks until I cry for attention (which isn't my style)

davidkhala (Wed, 28 Feb 2018 05:13:12 GMT):
@dave.enyeart Dear David, I saw https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/18087/ and found the commit is singed by two authors. As a new contributor, I am curious about how to do this. Is there any guideline about invite and cooperate with other contributors in single CR?

dave.enyeart (Wed, 28 Feb 2018 06:22:47 GMT):
@davidkhala Simply reach out to the initial contributor either via rocket.chat or gerrit review or jira to coordinate, and then you can Checkout the latest patch under gerrit Download link, make your updates, `git commit -s --amend` to update and sign the commit, then push as normal.

sheehan (Thu, 08 Mar 2018 21:53:40 GMT):
Most may already have it installed, but if you need to install Sphinx on High Sierra to review the doc CRs, there were some hoops I had to jump through. The procedure was ``` sudo pip install Sphinx --ignore-installed six sudo -H pip install sphinx_rtd_theme sudo pip install recommonmark ```

yacovm (Fri, 09 Mar 2018 21:42:28 GMT):

@cbf At I believe it was you one point you had pasted a very nice query for checking gerrit for reviews: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/q/is:open%20label:Verified%2B1%20%20NOT%20label:Code-Review-1%20NOT%20label:Code-Review-2%20is:mergeable Do you have a similar magic query for the new CI?

rjones (Thu, 12 Apr 2018 03:51:28 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/q/is:open%20label:F3-UnitTest=1%20is:mergeable

rjones (Thu, 12 Apr 2018 03:52:18 GMT):
I suppose there is a corner case there, @jyellick, where something could fail the documentation build but pass the functional builds. In practice, I haven't seen that.

Perfect, thanks!

smithbk (Wed, 02 May 2018 22:25:51 GMT):

you just can't strip DTCC's copyright, though

gennadyl (Wed, 16 May 2018 14:06:13 GMT):
What should I put there?

gennadyl (Wed, 16 May 2018 14:06:44 GMT):
Original copyright message broke the build

cbf (Wed, 16 May 2018 14:07:07 GMT):
so, we need to not touch the copyright

cbf (Wed, 16 May 2018 14:07:24 GMT):
the copyright itself is JUST the line that has "Copyright..."

cbf (Wed, 16 May 2018 14:07:33 GMT):
the prose AFTER that is the license header

cbf (Wed, 16 May 2018 14:07:48 GMT):
that is being replaced by the SPDX line

gennadyl (Wed, 16 May 2018 14:07:54 GMT):
Ok, will change it

cbf (Wed, 16 May 2018 14:07:57 GMT):
and we should not add IBM copyright

gennadyl (Wed, 16 May 2018 14:08:12 GMT):
Got it

jyellick (Wed, 16 May 2018 14:10:23 GMT):
A request to other maintainers. I know we are looking to get this CR backlog closed, but I've seen some CRs merged which still had outstanding comments. Let's be careful to ensure that we're not discarding reviews for expediency.

yacovm (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:52:14 GMT):
and also - a general question - if the delta between patch set `i` to patch set `i+1` is only auto-generated code, do you 100% have to add a signed-off-by?

yacovm (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:52:18 GMT):
that was the case here, btw

yacovm (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:52:34 GMT):
because, technically speaking - the code wasn't written by him, but by a tool

yacovm (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:52:56 GMT):
so wondering.... @cbf maybe you can also answer this?

rjones (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:53:46 GMT):
Someone is committing the code. They need to attest to that

yacovm (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:54:16 GMT):
well, but if you do a rebase - we don't enforce that

yacovm (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:54:20 GMT):
right?

rjones (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:54:46 GMT):
On trivial rebar, correct

rjones (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:54:46 GMT):
On trivial rebase, correct

rjones (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:56:19 GMT):
There is no code change for a trivial rebase. If you do a rebase -i to solve merge conflicts you would need to sign

yacovm (Wed, 16 May 2018 15:57:05 GMT):
ok

Maria (Tue, 29 May 2018 14:23:30 GMT):
just fyi - https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/22189/ (not yet working) is an e2e test that tests ca, sdk and fabric core, we identified the issue (in the encodings of attributes and keys between different components, so not crypto-related issues) and completing the fix now.

Maria (Tue, 29 May 2018 14:23:30 GMT):
just fyi - https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/22189/ (not yet working) is an e2e test that tests ca, sdk and fabric core, we identified the issue (in the encodings of attributes and keys between different components, so not crypto-related issues) and completing the fix now. but to fix that we need to update the whole stack of commits in sdk, thus some CRs are not rebased yes, since we have to do them one-by-one.

Maria (Tue, 29 May 2018 14:23:30 GMT):
just fyi - https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/22189/ (not yet working) is an e2e test that tests ca, sdk, and fabric core all together. We identified the issue (in the encodings of attributes and keys between different components, so not crypto-related issues) and completing the fix now. but to fix that we need to update the whole stack of commits in sdk, thus some CRs are not rebased yes, since we have to do them one-by-one.

Maria (Tue, 29 May 2018 14:23:30 GMT):
just fyi - https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/22189/ (not yet working) is an e2e test that tests ca, sdk, and fabric core all together. We identified the issue (in the encodings of attributes and keys between different components, so not crypto-related issues) and completing the fix now. But to fix that we need to update the whole stack of commits in sdk, thus some CRs are not rebased yet, since we have to do them one-by-one.

Maria (Tue, 29 May 2018 14:23:30 GMT):
just fyi - https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/22189/ (not yet working) is an e2e test that tests ca, sdk, and fabric core all together. We identified the issue (in the encodings of revealed attribute values and keys between different components, so not crypto-related issues) and completing the fix now. But to fix that we need to update the whole stack of commits in sdk, thus some CRs are not rebased yet, since we have to do them one-by-one.

cbf (Tue, 12 Jun 2018 20:04:36 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/22993 @mastersingh24 @rameshthoomu @kostas @greg.haskins this CR adds a new metadata property to track the commit sha, it also hard codes the version so that we can pursue the stable image strategy. It also has a side effect that it resolves FAB-8559 to the extent that was an issue (it had a workaround).

cbf (Tue, 12 Jun 2018 20:06:36 GMT):
note that this could have been DRYed up but will reserve that for post 1.2 because there is likely to be other refactoring of the commandline tools anywho

wlahti (Wed, 20 Jun 2018 22:28:04 GMT):
Even though the deliver service is the preferred event method these days, the eventhub is nevertheless still part of the project and used. This CR attempts to fix a major issue where the flow of events from the eventhub can completely stop for all clients if a single problematic client connection holds on to the grpc connection: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/23179/

yacovm (Wed, 17 Oct 2018 14:55:16 GMT):
@adc I reviewed... IMO all that is needed is to replace the marshal with marshalOrPanic and it's good to go

yacovm (Wed, 17 Oct 2018 14:55:34 GMT):
we should never mark transactions invalid if we fail to *marshal*.

yacovm (Wed, 17 Oct 2018 14:55:58 GMT):
if you fail to *marshal* a protobuf then something is wrong with your binary and it smells like none determinism to me

yacovm (Wed, 17 Oct 2018 19:38:04 GMT):
bug fix https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/27066/

joe-alewine (Fri, 22 Mar 2019 19:39:23 GMT):
Open Raft-lated doc CRs: Raft tutorial: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/30332/ (newest push, has no comments yet) Orderer concept: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/29449/ (has gone through several rounds of comments) Configure Raft: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/30010/ (has gone through several rounds of comments, though decisions about what should go in doc are still pending) Glossary updates: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/30182/ (wording here taken from concept doc --- if you feel good about the concept doc, you should feel good about this) Stand up orderer node (implementation agnostic): https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/30242/ (could use more help) Add Raft option to BYFN (checked out against `release-1.4`): https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/30238/ (small change) Add Raft to Intro doc: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/30189/ (tiny change) Add Raft to What's New doc: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/30187/ (summary of major docs being pushed here) Add Raft to Upgrade: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/30196/ (small references to Raft) Add links to Kafka doc: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/30183/ (small change --- majority is formatting changes) As I've said before, many of these CRs are rather small. In some cases, only a few words followed by a link. I very much appreciate everyone's comments so far, and to come.

sstone1 (Mon, 29 Jul 2019 10:49:43 GMT):
can someone review this CR please? it updates the CLI to run endorsements across multiple peers concurrently (should help resolve some sample CI failures): https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/fabric/+/32531

jyellick (Tue, 30 Jul 2019 20:09:58 GMT):
Is anyone aware of and working on the fact that master is broken right now?

jyellick (Tue, 30 Jul 2019 20:10:55 GMT):
Looks like fe96878a1a9150b135021ac85b731cdd250e495c causes `github.com/hyperledger/fabric/internal/peer/chaincode` `TestQueryCmdEndorsementFailure` to fail

jyellick (Tue, 30 Jul 2019 20:27:05 GMT):
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/c/fabric/+/32595

yacovm (Tue, 30 Jul 2019 20:35:35 GMT):
how did it pass CI?

jyellick (Tue, 30 Jul 2019 20:37:29 GMT):
Basically, the optimization introduced by fe96878 seeks endorsements in parallel. So, the order they are returned in is arbitrary. In this test, there are two endorsements, and the code simply checks the first one. On my machine, the second seems to be consistently chosen, but I guess CI got (un)lucky and ordered them the other way.

yacovm (Tue, 30 Jul 2019 20:38:21 GMT):
> On my machine, the second seems to be consistently chosen, wow... your `/dev/random` is broken, Jason

yacovm (Tue, 30 Jul 2019 20:38:21 GMT):
> On my machine, the second seems to be consistently chosen, wow... your `/dev/urandom` is broken, Jason

yacovm (Tue, 30 Jul 2019 20:38:24 GMT):
;)

jyellick (Tue, 30 Jul 2019 20:41:14 GMT):
Must be the low entropy qualities of `/dev/urandom`, I'll have to submit a patch upstream so that `go` uses `/dev/random` in its scheduler just to be sure :)

sstone1 (Wed, 31 Jul 2019 09:17:59 GMT):
oops - thanks for fixing @jyellick !

sstone1 (Wed, 31 Jul 2019 09:18:28 GMT):
the test isn't really valid either - you can only use `peer chaincode query` against a single peer

rjones (Sun, 27 Oct 2019 18:26:09 GMT):
I added some reviewers

BrettLogan (Sun, 27 Oct 2019 20:21:25 GMT):
@SamYuan1990 you should have amended your original CR instead of putting a separate change in to fix the linting error. Doing it the way you did will cause the merge to fail in CI with the same linting error, as well as making git bisects harder to achieve. Please pull your latest commit and squash them into a single CR

BrettLogan (Sun, 27 Oct 2019 20:21:25 GMT):
@SamYuan1990 you should have amended your original CR instead of putting a separate change in to fix the linting error. Doing it the way you did will cause the merge to fail in CI with the same linting error, as well as making got bisects easier to achieve. Please pull your latest commit and squash them into a single CR
